item.title: The Chill Out
item.description:
The Chill Out
The Chill Out is a relaxing stress relief event hosted by Student Wellness, a collaboration of Health Promotion, Counseling Services, and Student Health Services. Take a break and unwind with calming activities like dog therapy, coloring, crafting, sand gardens, and aromatherapy. Whether you're looking to recharge or just need a moment of peace, come chill out with us and give your mind and body the care they deserve.

From Wednesday, October 22, 2025 11:00 AM to 2:00 PM EDT at Student Union 145 and 235.
item.author: stu-wellnessed@buffalo.edu (Health Promotion)

item.title: Us-You=Me
item.description:
Us-You=Me

There are three parts to any relationship (friendships, familial or romantic); me, you and us. Sometimes in relationships we sacrifice the 'me' for the sake of the 'us'. Join us for a conversation about how to maintain the 'me' in a relationship by exploring personal values, boundaries and what we want out of relationships.

From Wednesday, October 22, 2025 2:00 PM to 3:00 PM EDT at 210 Student Union (North Campus).

item.title: Presentation and Slide Development Workshop
item.description:
Presentation and Slide Development Workshop

Discover how to transform your presentations from cluttered and forgettable to clear, engaging and memorable. This workshop explores the principles of effective slide design and delivery, emphasizing simplicity, emotional connection and storytelling. Whether you're presenting data or ideas, you'll leave with practical strategies to make your message stick.

 

For those connected to Roswell Park, please RSVP by completing this online form.

From Wednesday, October 22, 2025 3:00 PM to 4:00 PM EDT at 104 Alfiero Center (North Campus).

item.title: BIPOC Drop-In Support Group
item.description:
BIPOC Drop-In Support Group

This drop-in group is committed to providing an affirming space for BIPOC students to reflect on their experiences at a PWI. In this group, we recognize the unique experiences of BIPOC students and aim to foster a community for students to give voice to their experiences, gain support, and develop healthy coping strategies. All are welcome.

From Wednesday, October 22, 2025 3:00 PM to 4:30 PM EDT at SU 240.

item.title: Yoga for Beginners with Jackie
item.description:
Yoga for Beginners with Jackie
This class is for every person who "isn't flexible", "doesn't have good balance", and "can't sit still". Come find your body's expression of yoga! This in-person yoga class is for EVERYONE! Classes will consist of movements that focus on functional range of motion and provide an introduction to yoga postures. Options for modifications or deepening of postures will be included. Breath awareness and meditation will be introduced as the semester progresses.
 
No experience is necessary, please come dressed comfortably. Please bring a yoga mat or towel, and a water bottle. All other props will be provided. Classes are first-come, first-served. Please arrive early to get a space and set up. Classes do fill up and may be closed. 

From Wednesday, October 22, 2025 4:00 PM to 5:00 PM EDT at Richmond 271- Aerobics Room.
item.author: stu-wellnessed@buffalo.edu (Health Promotion)

item.title: Lights, Law, Legacy: Honoring Black Excellence in Law
item.description:
Lights, Law, Legacy: Honoring Black Excellence in Law

Lights, Law, Legacy is more than just an event, it’s a space to honor and reflect on the power of Black excellence in law. Together, we’ll celebrate the trailblazers who paved the way, from Thurgood Marshall and Constance Baker Motley to Justice Ketanji Brown Jackson, and explore how their stories continue to inspire us today.

There’ll be an interactive slideshow with visuals and clips, moments for open discussion, and a short reflection where everyone can share what Black excellence in law means to them. We’ll close with a “Legacy Reflection,” where members write one word or thought that captures what they’re taking away from the experience.

From Wednesday, October 22, 2025 4:00 PM to 5:00 PM EDT at Capen 257.
item.author: Ub.blsaprelaw@gmail.com (Pre-Law Chapter of the National Black Law Students Association )
item.host: Pre-Law Chapter of the National Black Law Students Association

item.title: IEEE Micromouse and Automated Greenhouse Project Meeting
item.description:
IEEE Micromouse and Automated Greenhouse Project Meeting

IEEE will be hosting the weekly meeting for Micromouse and Automated Greenhouse during this meeting time. 

Micromouse: Build an autonomous maze solving robot and compete against others! UB IEEE targets the annual Region 1 and 2 Micromouse Student Competition and annual Applied Power and Electronics (APEC) Micromouse Competition. This is a great opportunity for those who love embedded systems, software-hardware integration, competition, and working with a team! Our individual small micromouse teams will continue to work on their own maze-solving robots. 

Automated Greenhouse: This project aims to create an autonomous greenhouse that can be used to grow and monitor plants with minimal human intervention. The goal is to keep plants alive and healthy by itself over long periods of time (such as over a winter or summer break). The goal for this year is to create a basic structure that can grow foods such as grape tomatoes and basil. This project is looking for people interested in web development, embedded systems, Internet of Things (IoT), gardening, sustainability, and building! 

 

From Wednesday, October 22, 2025 4:30 PM to 7:30 PM EDT at Bonner 416.

item.title: General Body Meeting
item.description:
General Body Meeting

The UB YDSA mission is multi-faceted: To educate and organize (primarily) students and young people. To play a helpful and principled role in local movements for social justice. To make meaningful change for a more just world. Within and throughout this struggle, we will articulate and defend the idea that true human liberation is impossible under capitalism. We seek social change that extends democracy into all aspects of life ‚Äê‚Äê social, political, and economic.

From Wednesday, October 22, 2025 7:00 PM to 8:00 PM EDT at Clemen 120.

item.title: The Hardcore Challenge
item.description:
The Hardcore Challenge

Ready to take on the ultimate test of strength and endurance?  

The Hardcore Challenge brings together the best of both worlds – pushing your body and mind to new limits. Designed for UB students, this challenge invites participants to go for records in four classic feats: most pushups, most pull-ups, longest planks, and longest dead hang.  

Whether you’re here to set a new personal best or just want to jump in for the fun of it, this event is open to all levels – no prior training required. Come challenge yourself, cheer on your friends, and see what you’re capable of! 

 

From Wednesday, October 22, 2025 5:00 PM to 8:00 PM EDT at Alumni Arena.

item.title: Table Tennis Practice
item.description:

item.title: Community Assistant Information Session
item.description:
Community Assistant Information Session
Come to an Information Session to learn more about the Community Assistant (CA) position for the 2026–2027 academic year at the University at Buffalo! This session will cover everything you need to know about the role, including responsibilities, renumeration, and how to apply. Being a CA is a great opportunity to build leadership skills, connect with the campus community, and make a positive impact in UB’s residence halls and apartments. Whether you're seriously considering applying or just want to explore your options, this session is a great place to start!
 
The Community Assistant (CA) is previously known as Resident Assistant (RA) and Academic Assistant (AA).

From Thursday, October 23, 2025 12:00 PM to 1:00 PM EDT at Greiner Hall C-Wing Classroom.

We offer dynamic and reverent worship, compassionate pastoral care, and opportunities for transformative volunteer service, spiritual retreats, theological discussions, social justice advocacy, free meals, and more! item.description:
AR Body Doubling Sessions: Thursdays

Join Accessibility Resources in body doubling sessions every week on Thursday. Body doubling is a productive strategy in which people work alongside each other to complete tasks that they might otherwise find challenging. Join virtually and work with other students, helping you focus on your tasks. Thursday's session will be hybrid.

item.description:
How to Help a Sexual Assault Survivor

Every academic year hundreds of new and incoming students reported experiencing sexual violence. Learn how to respond if someone you know experiences sexual violence. Participants will learn how to help others recover from rape and sexual assault, tap into local resources, and get involved with prevention efforts at UB. Additional resources can be found online.

item.description:

Ready to secure the pay you deserve? This workshop equips you with essential skills to negotiate confidently, whether it’s for a new job, promotion, or raise. 

Negotiating isn’t just about earning more—it’s about valuing yourself and building professional confidence. Through expert tips and practice exercises, you’ll leave prepared to advocate for your worth and take control of your career.

item.title: Solar Splash Meeting
item.description:
Solar Splash Meeting

The American Society of Mechanical Engineers presents: 

Solar Splash

The Solar Splash project is a solar-powered motorboat that combines renewable energy with efficient design. The remaining tasks include completing the electrical work for the batteries and solar panels, installing a bracket for the steering system, adding an emergency shut-off switch, setting up the bilge pump, and making cosmetic modifications to refine the boat’s appearance and functionality. Once complete, the boat will compete in a series of races this summer against other schools.

From Thursday, October 23, 2025 4:00 PM to 5:00 PM EDT at Jarvis 305.

item.title: Yoga for Student Well-being: Thursdays with Tara
item.description:
Yoga for Student Well-being: Thursdays with Tara
This in-person yoga class consists of yoga postures/movements, meditation, and breath awareness to maintain balance and overall wellness through the challenges of the semester. It is not a fitness class, yet you may choose to test your limits. This class has extended relaxation time at the end. No experience is necessary. All levels are welcome, and all body types and sizes are honored. Dress comfortably. Please bring a towel/yoga mat and a water bottle. If you attend two classes, you can get a free yoga mat! Come every week or drop in when you can. Classes are first come, first serve. Arrive early to get a space in the class. Classes do fill up and may be closed upon arrival.
 
 

From Thursday, October 23, 2025 4:00 PM to 5:15 PM EDT at Richmond 271- Aerobics Room.

item.description:
Identify Your Stressors Pt 1

Join Accessibility Resources and the Institute on Trauma and Trauma Informed Care to delve deeper into proactive strategies to help us stay emotionally regulated. We will review example regulation and coregulation strategies, and discuss how to schedule proactive brain breaks to manage dysregulation. This is part one of a two-part workshop. There will be time integrated into this workshop to practice the skills you learn. This is a hybrid workshop.

It’s a great way to apply what you’ve learned, build confidence, and enjoy some friendly competition, with prizes to win and leadership skills to grow.

item.title: Philosophy, Politics, and Economics Club Weekly Meeting
item.description:
Philosophy, Politics, and Economics Club Weekly Meeting

The purpose of the Philosophy, Politics, and Economics (PPE) Club is to provide a space for the open discussion of topics related to the intersection of philosophy, political science, and economics and foster an intellectual community based on mutual respect and curiosity. Join us each week for great conversations about unique topics, lots of fun, and a community like no other on campus (and also pizza).

PPE Club is open to people of all majors and disciplines. Regardless of your background, knowledge of the topics, or future aspirations, PPE Club has something for everyone! PPE Club also serves to connect students with the academic and professional opportunities that are available for those passionate about the humanities and social sciences. Students have made connections through PPE Club that led them to research opportunities, internships, and more. We hope to see you there!

From Thursday, October 23, 2025 5:00 PM to 6:00 PM EDT at SU 210 Landmark Room.

item.title: UB Votes Committee Candidate Forum
item.description:
UB Votes Committee Candidate Forum

This is a nonpartisan Candidates Forum for the Amherst Town Supervisor election, organized by the UB Votes Committee in collaboration with Student Engagement, Community Relations, academic departments, and external community partners. The purpose of the forum is to provide students, faculty, staff, and community members with an opportunity to hear directly from candidates about their platforms and approaches to public service. The event is being conducted in partnership with the League of Women Voters of Buffalo Niagara, who will oversee the forum procedures to ensure neutrality and compliance with nonpartisan standards. The forum aligns with UB’s civic engagement goals and offers an educational opportunity for the campus and surrounding community.

“Pure Monotheism: Understanding Tawheed” is an in-depth look at the Islamic belief in the oneness of Allah, known as tawheed. It covers how the early generations of Muslims (the Salaf) understood and explained this core aspect of faith, including its categories, meanings, and relevance to a Muslim’s worship and daily life.

item.title: Ceremony of Mehregan
item.description:
Ceremony of Mehregan

Mehregan (Persian: ŸÖŸáÿ±⁄ØÿßŸÜ) or Jashn-e Mehr (ÿ¨ÿ¥ŸÜ ŸÖŸáÿ± lit. Mithra Festival) is a Zoroastrian and Iranian festival celebrated to honor the yazata Mithra (Persian: Mehr), which is responsible for friendship, affection and love.
"Mehregan" is derived from the Middle Persian name MihrakƒÅn/MihragƒÅn, itself derived from Old Persian MithrakƒÅna.
This is an Iranian festival honoring the Zoroastrian yazata Mithra.Under the Achaemenid Empire (330–550 BC), the Armenian subjects of the Persian king gave him 20,000 horses every year during the celebration of Mehregan. Under the Sasanian Empire (224–651), Mehregan was the second most important festival, falling behind Nowruz. Due to these two festivals being heavily connected with the role of Iranian kingship, the Sasanian rulers were usually crowned on either Mehregan or Nowruz.

All participants must review the GSA's Safety Acknowledgement and Participant Disclaimer before attending. 

 

 

From Friday, October 24, 2025 4:00 PM to 6:00 PM EDT at SU 210 Landmark Room.

item.title: Take2 Tihar with Nepalese Student Association
item.description:
Take2 Tihar with Nepalese Student Association

Tihar is one of the two largest festivals of Nepal.  Nepali Tihar Night is a vibrant cultural celebration that brings together the spirit, colors, and traditions of Nepal’s beloved festival, Tihar. Often called the “Festival of Lights,” Tihar is a time when families honor animals, celebrate prosperity, and strengthen bonds between brothers and sisters through rituals like Bhai Tika. At Tihar Night, guests can experience this unique heritage through lively music, traditional Nepali dances, authentic cuisine, and dazzling decorations of lights and rangoli. It is more than just a celebration—it is a warm invitation to immerse yourself in Nepali culture, community, and joy.

This year Nepalese Student Association is hosting Tihar Night. This is a good opportunity to learn about a new culture and immerse yourself into it.

From Friday, October 24, 2025 5:45 PM to 6:45 PM EDT at Clemens 120.

item.title: Unplug and Play: UB REC Halloween
item.description:
Unplug and Play: UB REC Halloween

A program for students, by students, Unplug & Play brings you all the feels of family game night with some life-sized additions. UB Rec & the Bulls Team Shop have teamed up to offer UB Students a weekly night of fun, games, popcorn, music and major shopping sales!

Discover a refreshing and tech-free approach to fun at UB Recreation with our Unplug & Play program! Enjoy inclusive, low-stress activities featuring giant games like Jenga, Corn Hole, and Connect-4, accessible to all skill levels. Experience classic and giant games like chess, checkers, ping-pong, and Yahtzee, along with creative activities like coloring pages, ensuring everyone has a well-rounded and enjoyable time.

UB Students, don't miss out! Enjoy 20% OFF at the Bulls Team Shop every Friday* from 5pm - 8pm in Alumni Arena. Join us for fun and games!

*Unplug & Play programming is only available during the fall and spring semester. Hours are Subject to Change.

More info: https://www.buffalo.edu/recreation/we-have-fun/open-rec--programs/unplug-and-play.html

Also check out our other Halloween Traditions:

Glow Zumba: 10/27 @6PM in 75 Alumni Arena

item.title: Serve or Scare! ‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è Evans Quad RHA
item.description:
Serve or Scare! ‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è Evans Quad RHA

It was a dark and stormy night... Ô∏è‚ö°

Students gathered at The Landing in Fargo Quad for the spooky Serve or Scare event, running from 7PM to 10PM.

Everything started out fun, laughter at the potion station (mocktail station) , sweet bites of apple cider and donuts , and creative chaos at pumpkin painting . But when someone tried axe throwing, the power flickered...

Suddenly, the Red Bull Tetris challenge began... (winner gets to go to the national challenge and could potentially win a trip to Miami) but the blocks weren’t moving on screen... they were falling from the ceiling!

Students ran toward the costume contest, thinking it was safe... until the winner’s mask started to move on its own. Ô∏èÔ∏è

By 10PM, only one thing was clear: no one truly served, and everyone got scared.

From Friday, October 24, 2025 7:00 PM to 10:00 PM EDT at The Landing, University at Buffalo.

item.description:

Greetings to the Ghouls and Goblins at Evans Quad,
The chill in the air means one thing… it’s time for Serve or Scare!  Join us at The Landing from 7PM to 10PM on Friday, October 24th for a night filled with frightfully fun activities:
 Potion Station (Mocktail Station)
 Apple Cider & Donuts
 Pumpkin Painting
 Axe Throwing
 Halloween Trivia with Prizes
 Grand Costume Contest
 Plus, a Red Bull Tetris Challenge you won’t want to miss!
Come dressed to impress (or distress) and get ready for a night that’s equal parts spooky and sweet.
See you there… if you dare. 

From Friday, October 24, 2025 7:00 PM to 10:00 PM EDT at The Landing.

item.title: Bulls Beyond UB | Frightworld
item.description:
Bulls Beyond UB | Frightworld

Experience all the Halloween vibes at Frightworld! On this free trip, you will have a frightening and fun experience at 5 haunted houses: Mainframe Massacre, Carnival Boneyard, Grindhouse, Nightstalkers Reloaded, and Eerie State Asylum! 

Admission tickets and transportation are completely free for students! 

Departure: 6:00 pm from Student Union.

Return: Buses return to campus at 11:30 p.m.  

Students who wish to attend need to RSVP no later than Thursday, October 23! Students who RSVP will receive a Confirmation or Waitlist email prior to the event date with more information.

Due to high demand for this event, Student Engagement will provide transportation to students on a shuttle system to Frightworld. Students who are confirmed for this trip based on their RSVP time will be provided free transportation and admission. Students who are on the waitlist may be provided free transportation, but will need to purchase their own ticket at Frightworld. 

Don't miss this thrilling and fun opportunity! 

From Saturday, October 25, 2025 6:00 PM to 11:30 PM EDT at Frightworld.
item.author: leadub@buffalo.edu (Student Engagement)

item.title: H2O Sunday Service
item.description:
H2O Sunday Service
 

The purpose of our Sunday Service is to gather together to worship God as a family. We believe that it is not just a meeting, but an opportunity to hear from God through His Word and through others. No matter where you are in your faith journey, you are welcome to join us as you are every Sunday.

You can expect:

  • Authentic worship music so that we may praise Him together
  • Solid Biblical teaching that applies to your life
  • Real stories about what God is doing in people’s lives
  • Conversation and fellowship before and after each gathering

Our Sunday Services are at 10:30am on campus every week! 

From Sunday, October 26, 2025 10:30 AM to 11:45 AM EDT at SU 330 Pride & Tradition Assembly Hall.

item.title: UB Badminton Open Play
item.description:
UB Badminton Open Play

UB Badminton hosts a weekly open play session every Sunday from 11 AM to 2 PM at the Triple Gym Alumni Arena. Players of all skill levels are welcome to join. We have 8 courts available, and we provide rackets and used birdies. The back 4 courts have a 20-minute rotation, while the front 4 courts operate on a waitlist system, allowing players up to 2 sets of games.

Please remember to bring your UBLINKED event pass for check-in. If you need to borrow a racket, be sure to bring your ID for rental. We look forward to seeing you on Sundays and hope you have a fantastic time at our open play session!

From Sunday, October 26, 2025 11:00 AM to 2:00 PM EDT at Triple Gym, Alumni Arena.

item.title: Chinese Mid-autumn Festival (Cancelled)
item.description:
Chinese Mid-autumn Festival

Join us for a joyful evening celebrating the Mid-Autumn Festival, one of the most beloved traditional Chinese holidays! The event will feature cultural performances, interactive games, mooncake tasting, and lantern displays, bringing together friends and families to share the warmth of reunion under the bright full moon.

Experience the beauty of Chinese culture through music, art, and storytelling, and learn about the legends behind this centuries-old festival. Whether you’re here to enjoy the delicious treats, admire the lanterns, or simply make new friends, this event promises an unforgettable cultural experience for everyone.

From Sunday, October 26, 2025 4:00 PM to 7:00 PM EDT at SU 210 Landmark Room.

item.title: Community Assistant Information Session
item.description:
Community Assistant Information Session
Come to an Information Session to learn more about the Community Assistant (CA) position for the 2026–2027 academic year at the University at Buffalo! This session will cover everything you need to know about the role, including responsibilities, renumeration, and how to apply. Being a CA is a great opportunity to build leadership skills, connect with the campus community, and make a positive impact in UB’s residence halls and apartments. Whether you're seriously considering applying or just want to explore your options, this session is a great place to start!
 
The Community Assistant (CA) is previously known as Resident Assistant (RA) and Academic Assistant (AA).

From Monday, October 27, 2025 1:00 PM to 2:00 PM EDT at Greiner Hall C-Wing Classroom.

item.title: Forge Competing at CalHacks 12.0
item.description:
Forge Competing at CalHacks 12.0

From October 24 – 26, select members of UB Forge, will be traveling to the Palace of Fine Arts in San Francisco, CA to compete at CalHacks 12.0, one of the largest collegiate hackathons in the world.

Our team will represent UB by designing and developing an original project over a 36-hour build sprint alongside top students from across North America. The event emphasizes applied computer science, teamwork, and creative problem-solving.

Participation in CalHacks offers students an opportunity to gain real-world experience, network with industry professionals, and showcase UB’s growing hacker and builder community.

From Friday, October 24, 2025 12:00 PM to Monday, October 27, 2025 5:00 PM EDT at Palace of Fine Arts in San Francisco, CA.

item.title: IAM3D Project Meeting
item.description:
IAM3D Project Meeting

Friday, September 5th at 5pm

Welcome to IAM3D! Come learn about CAD, 3D Printing, Electronics, Robotics and 3D Design as we work on our FPV Payload Mars Rover! We will be competing in the Innovative Additive Manufacturing 3D design competition (IAM3D) in April.

Our task is to design and build a first person view mars rover that can pick up different objects and drop them in a bucket, and the challenge is to 3D print as many parts as possible. Join our discord for more info and updates, hope to see you there! ASME discord (Meetings will NOT be in Jarvis 305)

From Monday, October 27, 2025 5:00 PM to 6:00 PM EDT at Jarvis 305.

item.title: Guest Speaker Series #1 MISA x UBSEC (Cancelled)
item.description:
Guest Speaker Series #1 MISA x UBSEC

Date: October 27th, 2025
Time: 5:00–6:00 PM
Location: Jacobs 106

Join the Management Information Systems Association (MISA) in collaboration with UBSEC for our first Guest Speaker Series of the semester, featuring Professor Kevin Cleary, Clinical Associate Professor in the Management Science and Systems Department at the University at Buffalo.

Professor Cleary brings nearly 20 years of industry experience in information security, enterprise infrastructure, and IT management—spanning roles from IT director and enterprise infrastructure manager to Chief Information Security Officer (CISO) at UB. He holds his CISSP certification and has worked in both higher education and private-sector environments ranging from startups to large corporations.

During this event, Professor Cleary will share insights from his professional journey, lessons learned in cybersecurity leadership, and advice for students pursuing careers in MIS, IT, and security. Students will have the opportunity to ask questions, gain valuable career perspectives, and connect directly with an experienced cybersecurity professional.

Don’t miss this chance to learn from one of UB’s top experts in technology and security!

From Monday, October 27, 2025 5:00 PM to 6:00 PM EDT at Jacobs 106.
item.author: ubmisa.official@gmail.com (Management Information Systems Association)

item.title: Exploratory Data Analysis (EDA)
item.description:
Exploratory Data Analysis (EDA)

This session introduces a key process in understanding and preparing data for modeling. We’ll cover techniques for data cleaning and preprocessing, exploring feature distributions, detecting outliers, and identifying correlations among variables.

Through hands-on activities, you’ll practice using matplotlib and seaborn to create insightful visualizations, including histograms, scatter plots, and heatmaps, to better interpret and communicate data patterns.

From Monday, October 27, 2025 5:00 PM to 6:00 PM EDT at Baldy 114.

item.title: ESW Precious Plastics Project
item.description:
ESW Precious Plastics Project

Did you know that a lot of the cheap plastic bottles you recycle go to the landfill anyways? Our Precious Plastics project aims to mitigate harmful plastic waste by compacting those low-quality plastics into energy-efficient building materials (eco-bricks)!

Join us in using engineering and material concepts to construct our very own plastic eco-bricks.

No prior knowledge is needed, this project is open to students of every discipline!

For more information and updates check out our socials

Instagram: https://www.instagram.com/esw_ub/

Discord: https://discord.gg/w2BN2Ju3

From Monday, October 27, 2025 6:00 PM to 7:00 PM EDT at Clemens 06.

item.title: BASIC Weekly Meeting
item.description:
BASIC Weekly Meeting

Every Monday night our club meet for our weekly meetings. At these meetings, we start at 8:00 pm with worship songs followed by prayer and announcements. Each week we have a different speaker come and give a message relevant to the theme of the semester. They are introduced after announcements to give there 15–30-minute message. After the message men and women break up into small groups to further discuss the message. These small groups are a time to discuss the message and how it is relevant in our lives. Then we close in prayer for any student needs or general issues going on and the night ends with everyone enjoying a time of fellowship and catching up with new and old friends. 

From Monday, October 27, 2025 8:00 PM to 9:30 PM EDT at SU 235.

Come to an Information Session to learn more about the Community Assistant (CA) position for the 2026–2027 academic year at the University at Buffalo! This session will cover everything you need to know about the role, including responsibilities, renumeration, and how to apply. Being a CA is a great opportunity to build leadership skills, connect with the campus community, and make a positive impact in UB’s residence halls and apartments. Whether you're seriously considering applying or just want to explore your options, this session is a great place to start!
 
The Community Assistant (CA) is previously known as Resident Assistant (RA) and Academic Assistant (AA).

item.title: Solar Splash Meeting
item.description:
Solar Splash Meeting

The American Society of Mechanical Engineers presents: 

Solar Splash

The Solar Splash project is a solar-powered motorboat that combines renewable energy with efficient design. The remaining tasks include completing the electrical work for the batteries and solar panels, installing a bracket for the steering system, adding an emergency shut-off switch, setting up the bilge pump, and making cosmetic modifications to refine the boat’s appearance and functionality. Once complete, the boat will compete in a series of races this summer against other schools.

item.title: Leadership by Design: Lead with Your Style
item.description:
Leadership by Design: Lead with Your Style

DISC assessments are used to improve productivity, communication, and teamwork. DiSCover your DiSC profile, boost your efficiency and build strong relationships. The workshop will discuss the principles behind DiSC and will help attendees examine their own communication style and will provide techniques on how to communicate more effectively with others. 

This assessment normally costs $30, but is FREE to you as a UB student! Take advantage of this opportunity. Learn more about your motivators, strengths, how you communicate, how you work on a team. DISC will give you tips on how to best work with others.

You MUST complete the RSVP by 10/21 or 11/6 to receive the DISC assessment code to get the link to complete the assessment and have your report compiled before the workshop.

REQUIRED Workshop to complete the Organizational Development Badge!

From Tuesday, October 28, 2025 4:00 PM to 5:30 PM EDT at 222 Student Union.

item.title: Feeling Your Yoga: Tuesdays with Cory
item.description:
Feeling Your Yoga: Tuesdays with Cory
This in-person yoga class consists of yoga postures/movements, meditation, and breath awareness to maintain balance and overall wellness through the challenges of the semester. It is not a fitness class, yet you may choose to test your limits. This class has extended relaxation time at the end. No experience is necessary. All levels are welcome, and all body types and sizes are honored. Dress comfortably. Please bring a towel/yoga mat and a water bottle. If you attend two classes, you can get a free yoga mat! Come every week or drop in when you can. Classes are first come, first serve. Arrive early to get a space in the class. Classes do fill up and may be closed upon arrival.

From Tuesday, October 28, 2025 6:15 PM to 7:15 PM EDT at 11 Talbert Hall.

item.title: Graduate Christian Fellowship (Cancelled)
item.description:
Graduate Christian Fellowship

The Graduate Christian Fellowship (GCF) at UB is a welcoming community of graduate students, professional students, and post-docs who are curious about Jesus and what his life, death, and resurrection mean for our work and for the world.

 

This semester, we are reading the book of Colossians, a letter that invites us to see all of life (our studies, our relationships, our work, and our world) through the lens of Christ. Written to a young community learning to follow Jesus in a complex cultural moment, Colossians speaks with surprising clarity to our own questions of identity, purpose, and hope.

From Tuesday, October 28, 2025 7:00 PM to 8:30 PM EDT at Online.

item.title: ASC Region 1 Competition Training
item.description:
ASC Region 1 Competition Training

The Region 1 ASC Competition Training is designed to prepare student teams for the Associated Schools of Construction (ASC) Region 1 Competition. This training provides participants with hands-on experience, industry insights, and practical guidance to strengthen their skills in estimating, scheduling, project management, and team collaboration.

Through a series of workshops, mock problems, and mentorship from industry professionals, students will gain a deeper understanding of real-world construction scenarios and competition expectations. The training emphasizes technical accuracy, time management, and effective communication—key components for success at the ASC competition.

This preparation ensures teams are well-equipped to perform under pressure and represent their schools with confidence and professionalism at the regional level.

From Tuesday, October 28, 2025 6:30 PM to 8:30 PM EDT at Cooke 127B.

item.title: Geography Graduate Students Writing Group
item.description:
Geography Graduate Students Writing Group

The graduate students' writing workshop is a place for graduate students in the Geography department to write together. This workshop lasts for two hours every week, where students have a focused time to write academic materials, like drafts of research papers, research proposals, dissertations, course assignments, or any other writing. Besides writing, you can also do other research work, like reading papers and analyzing data. This workshop has two main goals: (1) improve the productivity of students, and (2) to learn about the research work of peers. It is hybrid, so you can join in person or remotely. 

 

All attendees must review the GSA Safety Acknowledgement – Participation Disclaimer – Graduate Student Association before attending. 

From Wednesday, October 29, 2025 10:00 AM to 12:00 PM EDT at Graduate Lounge, 401 Wilkeson Quad.

item.title: Empathy in Action: Emotional Intelligence for Student Leaders
item.description:
Empathy in Action: Emotional Intelligence for Student Leaders
Emotional Intelligence has emerged as a significant factor in personal and professional success, often rivaling or surpassing the traditional measure of intelligence (IQ). This workshop aims to rpovide participants with a unique opportunity to explore and deepen their understanding of emotions while equipping them with practical strategies for building rapport and fostering meaningful connections with others.

This session fulfills one workshop requirement for the Organizational Development digital badge!

From Wednesday, October 29, 2025 12:30 PM to 1:00 PM EDT at SU 222.

item.title: CSTEP All of Us: Cultivating Diverse & Inclusive Health Data
item.description:
CSTEP All of Us: Cultivating Diverse & Inclusive Health Data

The “All of Us” Research Program aims to gather health data from a diverse group of one million or more people in the United States to accelerate research in precision medicine. The National Institutes of Health (NIH) program collects data from various sources, including surveys, electronic health records, genomic analyses, and physical measurements, to create a comprehensive and diverse dataset for researchers. This diverse dataset is intended to help researchers study the full range of factors influencing health and disease.

RSVP via: https://tinyurl.com/CSTEPAllofUs

From Wednesday, October 29, 2025 3:00 PM to 4:30 PM EDT at 305 Capen Library .

item.title: Yoga for Beginners with Jackie
item.description:
Yoga for Beginners with Jackie
This class is for every person who "isn't flexible", "doesn't have good balance", and "can't sit still". Come find your body's expression of yoga! This in-person yoga class is for EVERYONE! Classes will consist of movements that focus on functional range of motion and provide an introduction to yoga postures. Options for modifications or deepening of postures will be included. Breath awareness and meditation will be introduced as the semester progresses.
 
No experience is necessary, please come dressed comfortably. Please bring a yoga mat or towel, and a water bottle. All other props will be provided. Classes are first-come, first-served. Please arrive early to get a space and set up. Classes do fill up and may be closed. 

From Wednesday, October 29, 2025 4:00 PM to 5:00 PM EDT at Richmond 271- Aerobics Room.

item.title: Take 2: Rolling with Rejection
item.description:
Take 2: Rolling with Rejection

Rejection is never an easy thing to deal with, especially when it comes from someone we want. Some may refuse with a polite “No,” while others may be rude in their expressed disinterest. For those who have experienced rejection, it is an emotionally and physically unpleasant feeling and we don’t always respond to it well; come learn how we as men can address rejection in a healthy way.

From Wednesday, October 29, 2025 3:15 PM to 5:15 PM EDT at 330 Student Union.

Hear from Miranda Zobrest, UB alumni and Talent Acquisition Supervisor at Five Star Bank, as she shares her own career journey and introduces a recent UB graduate who has just started theirs. Together, they’ll explore the transition from student to professional, the realities of breaking into HR, and the skills and strategies that helped them thrive. item.title: IEEE Micromouse and Automated Greenhouse Project Meeting
item.description:
IEEE Micromouse and Automated Greenhouse Project Meeting

IEEE will be hosting the weekly meeting for Micromouse and Automated Greenhouse during this meeting time. 

Micromouse: Build an autonomous maze solving robot and compete against others! UB IEEE targets the annual Region 1 and 2 Micromouse Student Competition and annual Applied Power and Electronics (APEC) Micromouse Competition. This is a great opportunity for those who love embedded systems, software-hardware integration, competition, and working with a team! Our individual small micromouse teams will continue to work on their own maze-solving robots. 

Automated Greenhouse: This project aims to create an autonomous greenhouse that can be used to grow and monitor plants with minimal human intervention. The goal is to keep plants alive and healthy by itself over long periods of time (such as over a winter or summer break). The goal for this year is to create a basic structure that can grow foods such as grape tomatoes and basil. This project is looking for people interested in web development, embedded systems, Internet of Things (IoT), gardening, sustainability, and building!

item.title: Being NOBULL: Putting Bystander Intervention into Action
item.description:
Being NOBULL: Putting Bystander Intervention into Action

LIVE YOUR VALUES! Have you intervened in a situation to keep someone from being hurt or harmed? Why did you act instead of standing by? Chances are it is because it is in line with one of your personal values. Even though we all have a set of personal values, we do not always have the chance to our values. Let’s talk about ways to overcome the barriers to intervening and how to refine the skills you already have at Being NOBULL- Putting Bystander Intervention into Action. At the end of this program, participants will be able to: identify personal barriers to intervening, identify personal reasons for intervening, articulate their personal bystander intervention style and will begin developing plans for intervening if they see someone who needs help.

From Thursday, October 30, 2025 2:00 PM to 3:00 PM EDT at 330 Student Union (North Campus).

item.title: APhA Patient Counseling Competition
item.description:
APhA Patient Counseling Competition

If you enjoy applying your knowledge of pharmacy and want a fun way to practice these skills, then the annual APhA-ASP National Patient Counseling Competition is for you!

All student levels, P1-P4 (members and non-members), are invited and encouraged to participate. For those P4s that are interested we can make accommodations to allow you to compete virtually if you are not in the Buffalo area. The counseling competition starts at the local level here at UB, and there are a total of two rounds. Both rounds are run similarly to the counseling sessions that you complete in your Patient Care Essentials classes. The preliminary round includes a basic prescription that you, as the student pharmacist, have to counsel a mock patient on. You will receive time to review any drug database of your choosing to prepare what you would like to convey to the patient, similar to a real-life scenario.

Please note that you do not need extensive clinical knowledge to compete in this competition! The goal of this is to practice how you convey information to a patient and how you utilize your communication skills. From the preliminary round, the top ten students chosen by our pharmacist judges will move on to the final round here at UB. The final round will be run very similarly to the first round; however, it will be more challenging. The winner of the final round will have the chance of representing the University at Buffalo School of Pharmacy and Pharmaceutical Sciences at the APhA annual meeting by competing in a virtual preliminary round. If the
winner makes it past the virtual round, they will get to compete against other students from all over the country! The top ten finalists in the national competition will get recognized during the awards celebration at the annual meeting and even receive cash prizes!

This is a great way to practice counseling without a formal grade for a class, allowing you to just have a conversation with a patient! Both rounds will be held in the patient assessment room, so it should feel very familiar to what you have already been doing in your classes. Each round will be recorded as well, so there is
no pressure of judges watching you as you counsel.

From Thursday, October 30, 2025 3:00 PM to 4:00 PM EDT at PB 250.

The American Society of Mechanical Engineers presents: 

Solar Splash

The Solar Splash project is a solar-powered motorboat that combines renewable energy with efficient design. The remaining tasks include completing the electrical work for the batteries and solar panels, installing a bracket for the steering system, adding an emergency shut-off switch, setting up the bilge pump, and making cosmetic modifications to refine the boat’s appearance and functionality. Once complete, the boat will compete in a series of races this summer against other schools.

It is not a fitness class, yet you may choose to test your limits. This class has extended relaxation time at the end. No experience is necessary. All levels are welcome, and all body types and sizes are honored. Dress comfortably. Please bring a towel/yoga mat and a water bottle. If you attend two classes, you can get a free yoga mat! item.description:

The purpose of the Philosophy, Politics, and Economics (PPE) Club is to provide a space for the open discussion of topics related to the intersection of philosophy, political science, and economics and foster an intellectual community based on mutual respect and curiosity. Join us each week for great conversations about unique topics, lots of fun, and a community like no other on campus (and also pizza).

PPE Club is open to people of all majors and disciplines. Regardless of your background, knowledge of the topics, or future aspirations, PPE Club has something for everyone! PPE Club also serves to connect students with the academic and professional opportunities that are available for those passionate about the humanities and social sciences. Students have made connections through PPE Club that led them to research opportunities, internships, and more. We hope to see you there!

From Thursday, October 30, 2025 5:00 PM to 6:00 PM EDT at SU 210 Landmark Room.

item.title: Pure Monotheism: Understanding Tawheed
item.description:
Pure Monotheism: Understanding Tawheed

“Pure Monotheism: Understanding Tawheed” is an in-depth look at the Islamic belief in the oneness of Allah, known as tawheed. It covers how the early generations of Muslims (the Salaf) understood and explained this core aspect of faith, including its categories, meanings, and relevance to a Muslim’s worship and daily life.

From Thursday, October 30, 2025 5:00 PM to 8:30 PM EDT at O'Brian 112.

item.title: Community Assistant Information Session
item.description:
Community Assistant Information Session
Come to an Information Session to learn more about the Community Assistant (CA) position for the 2026–2027 academic year at the University at Buffalo! This session will cover everything you need to know about the role, including responsibilities, renumeration, and how to apply. Being a CA is a great opportunity to build leadership skills, connect with the campus community, and make a positive impact in UB’s residence halls and apartments. Whether you're seriously considering applying or just want to explore your options, this session is a great place to start!
 
The Community Assistant (CA) is previously known as Resident Assistant (RA) and Academic Assistant (AA).

From Thursday, October 30, 2025 8:00 PM to 9:00 PM EDT at Evans Quad Main Lounge.

item.description:
Weekly UB FAN Fridays (GBM via Zoom)

Join us for a weekly virtual open space where UB FAN Leaders and Alumni Mentors come together to connect, share, and support one another. These informal sessions blend office hours, alumni highlights, and community-building topics to foster meaningful engagement between students and alumni. Whether you have questions, want to hear inspiring stories, or just want to pop in and say hi — all are welcome! Sessions will be led by Laura Masse (Assistant Director of Early Engagement) and FAN Managers, Emaan Sohail and Dessi Furber. Questions or want to formally join UB FAN? item.title: CSTEP Research Luncheon A
item.description:
CSTEP Research Luncheon A

You're invited to our CSTEP Research Luncheon A on Friday, October 31, 2025 at Noon in 104 O'Brian. Lunch will be provided. You must RSVP. 

Get a first-hand look at the amazing work our research interns who are talented undergraduate students in STEM in and the licensed professions. This is a great time to ask questions about their faculty-mentored research experience and our Summer Research Program and to hear about what CSTEP has to offer.

We will provide information about upcoming CSTEP events this fall! 

This is event is open to CSTEP students and those interested in applying to CSTEP. 

You must RSVP by Wed, October 29 at: https://www.tinyurl.com/CSTEPResearchLunchA

 

From Friday, October 31, 2025 12:00 PM to 1:30 PM EDT at 104 O'Brian Hall .

item.description:
AR Body Doubling Sessions: Fridays

Join Accessibility Resources in body doubling sessions every week on Friday. Body doubling is a productive strategy in which people work alongside each other to complete tasks that they might otherwise find challenging. Join virtually and work with other students, helping you focus on your tasks. Friday's session will be hybrid.

From Friday, October 31, 2025 4:00 PM to 6:00 PM EDT at Baldy 125.

item.title: IAM3D Project Meeting
item.description:
IAM3D Project Meeting

Friday, September 5th at 5pm

Welcome to IAM3D! Come learn about CAD, 3D Printing, Electronics, Robotics and 3D Design as we work on our FPV Payload Mars Rover! We will be competing in the Innovative Additive Manufacturing 3D design competition (IAM3D) in April.

Our task is to design and build a first person view mars rover that can pick up different objects and drop them in a bucket, and the challenge is to 3D print as many parts as possible. Join our discord for more info and updates, hope to see you there! ASME discord (Meetings will NOT be in Jarvis 305)

From Friday, October 31, 2025 5:00 PM to 6:00 PM EDT at Jarvis 305.
item.author: ubasme@gmail.com (American Society of Mechanical Engineers)

item.title: The Hardcore Challenge (Cancelled)
item.description:
The Hardcore Challenge

Ready to take on the ultimate test of strength and endurance?  

The Hardcore Challenge brings together the best of both worlds – pushing your body and mind to new limits. Designed for UB students, this challenge invites participants to go for records in four classic feats: most pushups, most pull-ups, longest planks, and longest dead hang.  

Whether you’re here to set a new personal best or just want to jump in for the fun of it, this event is open to all levels – no prior training required. Come challenge yourself, cheer on your friends, and see what you’re capable of! 

 

From Friday, October 31, 2025 5:00 PM to 6:00 PM EDT at Alumni Arena.

After our book chat, we’ll spend some time planning future non-book discussion night events, like movie nights, journaling sessions, or other fun activities to help us connect and relax outside of reading.

item.title: UB REC Halloween Week: Unplug and Play (Cancelled)
item.description:
UB REC Halloween Week: Unplug and Play

A program for students, by students, Unplug & Play brings you all the feels of family game night with some life-sized additions. UB Rec & the Bulls Team Shop have teamed up to offer UB Students a weekly night of fun, games, popcorn, music and major shopping sales!

Discover a refreshing and tech-free approach to fun at UB Recreation with our Unplug & Play program! Enjoy inclusive, low-stress activities featuring giant games like Jenga, Corn Hole, and Connect-4, accessible to all skill levels. Experience classic and giant games like chess, checkers, ping-pong, and Yahtzee, along with creative activities like coloring pages, ensuring everyone has a well-rounded and enjoyable time.

UB Students, don't miss out! Enjoy 20% OFF at the Bulls Team Shop every Friday* from 5pm - 8pm in Alumni Arena. Join us for fun and games!

*Unplug & Play programming is only available during the fall and spring semester. Hours are Subject to Change.

More info: https://www.buffalo.edu/recreation/we-have-fun/open-rec--programs/unplug-and-play.html

 

From Friday, October 31, 2025 5:00 PM to 8:00 PM EDT at Alumni Arena .

item.title: AIAA DBF (Design Build Fly) Build Meeting
item.description:
AIAA DBF (Design Build Fly) Build Meeting

UB AIAA is an engineering club that offers students hands-on experience with real-world aerospace challenges. The main project is Design/Build/Fly (DBF), an international competition hosted by AIAA, Textron Aviation, and Raytheon. DBF challenges teams to design, build, and fly a custom radio-controlled aircraft that meets a unique set of mission requirements. The club holds several meetings throughout the academic year to design and manufacture their RC aircraft. These meetings can range from CADing molds and parts of the plane, running tests to choose the airfoil shape, and hands-on meetings where members can work with carbon fiber or other materials to build the plane.

From Friday, October 31, 2025 6:00 PM to 8:00 PM EDT at Furnas Hall, Lab 1025.
item.author: buffaloaiaa@gmail.com (UB Chapter American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics)

item.title: H2O Sunday Service
item.description:
H2O Sunday Service
 

The purpose of our Sunday Service is to gather together to worship God as a family. We believe that it is not just a meeting, but an opportunity to hear from God through His Word and through others. No matter where you are in your faith journey, you are welcome to join us as you are every Sunday.

You can expect:

  • Authentic worship music so that we may praise Him together
  • Solid Biblical teaching that applies to your life
  • Real stories about what God is doing in people’s lives
  • Conversation and fellowship before and after each gathering

Our Sunday Services are at 10:30am on campus every week! 

From Sunday, November 2, 2025 10:30 AM to 11:45 AM EST at SU 330 Pride & Tradition Assembly Hall.
item.author: h2ochurchbuffalo@gmail.com (H2O Church)

item.title: UB Badminton Open Play
item.description:
UB Badminton Open Play

UB Badminton hosts a weekly open play session every Sunday from 11 AM to 2 PM at the Triple Gym Alumni Arena. Players of all skill levels are welcome to join. We have 8 courts available, and we provide rackets and used birdies. The back 4 courts have a 20-minute rotation, while the front 4 courts operate on a waitlist system, allowing players up to 2 sets of games.

Please remember to bring your UBLINKED event pass for check-in. If you need to borrow a racket, be sure to bring your ID for rental. We look forward to seeing you on Sundays and hope you have a fantastic time at our open play session!

From Sunday, November 2, 2025 11:00 AM to 2:00 PM EST at Triple Gym, Alumni Arena.

item.title: NSBE Regional Conference
item.description:
NSBE Regional Conference

The Fall Regional Conference (FRC) brings together over 700 members from across the Northeastern U.S. and Eastern Canada to advance the mission of NSBE: increasing the number of culturally responsible Black engineers who excel academically, succeed professionally, and positively impact the community. Guided by this year’s theme, Advancing S.T.E.M., the conference offers interactive workshops, a Career Fair, a Technical Research Exposition, and opportunities to network with peers and professionals. FRC is designed to equip members with the tools, resources, and inspiration to lead with excellence and “bring the FIYAH” as we continue engineering a brighter future.

From Thursday, October 30, 2025 3:00 PM to Sunday, November 2, 2025 6:00 PM EST at Lodge Street.

item.title: IAM3D Project Meeting
item.description:
IAM3D Project Meeting

Friday, September 5th at 5pm

Welcome to IAM3D! Come learn about CAD, 3D Printing, Electronics, Robotics and 3D Design as we work on our FPV Payload Mars Rover! We will be competing in the Innovative Additive Manufacturing 3D design competition (IAM3D) in April.

Our task is to design and build a first person view mars rover that can pick up different objects and drop them in a bucket, and the challenge is to 3D print as many parts as possible. Join our discord for more info and updates, hope to see you there! ASME discord (Meetings will NOT be in Jarvis 305)

From Monday, November 3, 2025 5:00 PM to 6:00 PM EST at Jarvis 305.

item.title: Guest Speaker Series #1 MISA x UBSEC
item.description:
Guest Speaker Series #1 MISA x UBSEC

Date: November 3rd, 2025
Time: 5:00–6:00 PM
Location: Jacobs 106

Join the Management Information Systems Association (MISA) in collaboration with UBSEC for our first Guest Speaker Series of the semester, featuring Professor Kevin Cleary and Professor Dominic Sellitto, both Clinical Associate Professors in the Management Science and Systems Department at the University at Buffalo.

Professor Kevin Cleary brings nearly 20 years of industry experience in information security, enterprise infrastructure, and IT management. With professional experience as  IT Director and Enterprise Infrastructure Manager to Chief Information Security Officer (CISO) at UB. He holds his CISSP certification and has worked in both higher education and private-sector environments ranging from startups to large corporations.

Professor Dominic Sellitto is the Faculty Director of the MS in Business Analytics program and Assistant Faculty Director of the Center for AI Business Innovation. With professional experience as a lead cybersecurity consultant and fractional CISO at Loptr LLC and as a Senior Consultant of Cyber Risk Services at Deloitte, he has led initiatives in governance, risk assessment, vulnerability management, and digital privacy. His teaching and research interests span cybersecurity, digital forensics, data warehousing, and AI usage and protection.

Together, Professors Cleary and Sellitto will share insights from their professional journeys, lessons in cybersecurity and business analytics, and advice for students pursuing careers in MIS, IT, and Cybersecurity. Attendees will have the opportunity to ask questions, gain valuable career perspectives, and network with two of UB’s leading experts in technology and cybersecurity.

Don’t miss this exciting opportunity to learn from two of UB’s top cybersecurity and analytics professionals!

From Monday, November 3, 2025 5:00 PM to 6:00 PM EST at Jacobs 106.
item.author: ubmisa.official@gmail.com (Management Information Systems Association)

item.title: ESW Precious Plastics Project
item.description:
ESW Precious Plastics Project

Did you know that a lot of the cheap plastic bottles you recycle go to the landfill anyways? Our Precious Plastics project aims to mitigate harmful plastic waste by compacting those low-quality plastics into energy-efficient building materials (eco-bricks)!

Join us in using engineering and material concepts to construct our very own plastic eco-bricks.

No prior knowledge is needed, this project is open to students of every discipline!

For more information and updates check out our socials

Instagram: https://www.instagram.com/esw_ub/

Discord: https://discord.gg/w2BN2Ju3

From Monday, November 3, 2025 6:00 PM to 7:00 PM EST at Clemens 06.

The WHWA is an on-campus organization dedicated to promoting and advocating for the equitable healthcare and overall wellness of all women. item.title: BASIC Weekly Meeting
item.description:
BASIC Weekly Meeting

Every Monday night our club meet for our weekly meetings. At these meetings, we start at 8:00 pm with worship songs followed by prayer and announcements. Each week we have a different speaker come and give a message relevant to the theme of the semester. They are introduced after announcements to give there 15–30-minute message. After the message men and women break up into small groups to further discuss the message. These small groups are a time to discuss the message and how it is relevant in our lives. Then we close in prayer for any student needs or general issues going on and the night ends with everyone enjoying a time of fellowship and catching up with new and old friends. 

From Monday, November 3, 2025 8:00 PM to 9:30 PM EST at SU 145 A+F+B+E.

item.title: Solar Splash Meeting
item.description:
Solar Splash Meeting

The American Society of Mechanical Engineers presents: 

Solar Splash

The Solar Splash project is a solar-powered motorboat that combines renewable energy with efficient design. The remaining tasks include completing the electrical work for the batteries and solar panels, installing a bracket for the steering system, adding an emergency shut-off switch, setting up the bilge pump, and making cosmetic modifications to refine the boat’s appearance and functionality. Once complete, the boat will compete in a series of races this summer against other schools.

From Tuesday, November 4, 2025 4:00 PM to 5:00 PM EST at Jarvis 305.

item.title: Feeling Your Yoga: Tuesdays with Cory
item.description:
Feeling Your Yoga: Tuesdays with Cory
This in-person yoga class consists of yoga postures/movements, meditation, and breath awareness to maintain balance and overall wellness through the challenges of the semester. It is not a fitness class, yet you may choose to test your limits. This class has extended relaxation time at the end. No experience is necessary. All levels are welcome, and all body types and sizes are honored. Dress comfortably. Please bring a towel/yoga mat and a water bottle. If you attend two classes, you can get a free yoga mat! Come every week or drop in when you can. Classes are first come, first serve. Arrive early to get a space in the class. Classes do fill up and may be closed upon arrival.

From Tuesday, November 4, 2025 6:15 PM to 7:15 PM EST at 11 Talbert Hall.

Life Groups are an essential weekly rhythm for H2O as they provide opportunity to know others and be known. You can expect to Study God’s Word, pray together, and be a part of a family who loves God together. Whether you’ve been in church your whole life or haven’t ever been, you are welcome to join us at Life Group.

item.title: Graduate Christian Fellowship (Cancelled)
item.description:
Graduate Christian Fellowship

The Graduate Christian Fellowship (GCF) at UB is a welcoming community of graduate students, professional students, and post-docs who are curious about Jesus and what his life, death, and resurrection mean for our work and for the world.

 

This semester, we are reading the book of Colossians, a letter that invites us to see all of life (our studies, our relationships, our work, and our world) through the lens of Christ. Written to a young community learning to follow Jesus in a complex cultural moment, Colossians speaks with surprising clarity to our own questions of identity, purpose, and hope.

From Tuesday, November 4, 2025 7:00 PM to 8:30 PM EST at Online.
item.author: chris.sullivan@intervarsity.org (Intervarsity Christian Fellowship)

item.title: ASC Region 1 Competition Training
item.description:
ASC Region 1 Competition Training

The Region 1 ASC Competition Training is designed to prepare student teams for the Associated Schools of Construction (ASC) Region 1 Competition. This training provides participants with hands-on experience, industry insights, and practical guidance to strengthen their skills in estimating, scheduling, project management, and team collaboration.

Through a series of workshops, mock problems, and mentorship from industry professionals, students will gain a deeper understanding of real-world construction scenarios and competition expectations. The training emphasizes technical accuracy, time management, and effective communication—key components for success at the ASC competition.

This preparation ensures teams are well-equipped to perform under pressure and represent their schools with confidence and professionalism at the regional level.

From Tuesday, November 4, 2025 6:30 PM to 8:30 PM EST at Cooke 127B.

item.title: Geography Graduate Students Writing Group
item.description:
Geography Graduate Students Writing Group

The graduate students' writing workshop is a place for graduate students in the Geography department to write together. This workshop lasts for two hours every week, where students have a focused time to write academic materials, like drafts of research papers, research proposals, dissertations, course assignments, or any other writing. Besides writing, you can also do other research work, like reading papers and analyzing data. This workshop has two main goals: (1) improve the productivity of students, and (2) to learn about the research work of peers. It is hybrid, so you can join in person or remotely. 

 

All attendees must review the GSA Safety Acknowledgement – Participation Disclaimer – Graduate Student Association before attending. 

From Wednesday, November 5, 2025 10:00 AM to 12:00 PM EST at Graduate Lounge, 401 Wilkeson Quad.

item.title: Yoga for Beginners with Jackie
item.description:
Yoga for Beginners with Jackie
This class is for every person who "isn't flexible", "doesn't have good balance", and "can't sit still". Come find your body's expression of yoga! This in-person yoga class is for EVERYONE! Classes will consist of movements that focus on functional range of motion and provide an introduction to yoga postures. Options for modifications or deepening of postures will be included. Breath awareness and meditation will be introduced as the semester progresses.
 
No experience is necessary, please come dressed comfortably. Please bring a yoga mat or towel, and a water bottle. All other props will be provided. Classes are first-come, first-served. Please arrive early to get a space and set up. Classes do fill up and may be closed. 

From Wednesday, November 5, 2025 4:00 PM to 5:00 PM EST at Richmond 271- Aerobics Room.

item.title: How to Help a Sexual Assault Survivor
item.description:
How to Help a Sexual Assault Survivor

Every academic year hundreds of new and incoming students reported experiencing sexual violence. Learn how to respond if someone you know experiences sexual violence. Participants will learn how to help others recover from rape and sexual assault, tap into local resources, and get involved with prevention efforts at UB. Additional resources can be found online. 

From Wednesday, November 5, 2025 4:00 PM to 5:00 PM EST at 210 Student Union (North Campus).
item.author: stu-wellnessed@buffalo.edu (Health Promotion)

item.title: What is a Portfolio and Why Do You Need One?
item.description:
What is a Portfolio and Why Do You Need One?

Portfolios are not just for Fine Arts majors anymore! Creating a portfolio and learning how to share it with potential employers and mentors can help you stand out among the crowd in this competitive STEM market for internships and full-time jobs. Your “portfolio” might be as simple as a few pictures on your phone or more elaborate like a portfolio website. We will discuss simple options to more creative, comprehensive options and how you might want to leverage your portfolio to get the most from it! This session is especially designed for any engineering major although anyone is welcome to attend.  

From Wednesday, November 5, 2025 4:00 PM to 5:00 PM EST at Capen 259.

item.title: IEEE Micromouse and Automated Greenhouse Project Meeting
item.description:
IEEE Micromouse and Automated Greenhouse Project Meeting

IEEE will be hosting the weekly meeting for Micromouse and Automated Greenhouse during this meeting time. 

Micromouse: Build an autonomous maze solving robot and compete against others! UB IEEE targets the annual Region 1 and 2 Micromouse Student Competition and annual Applied Power and Electronics (APEC) Micromouse Competition. This is a great opportunity for those who love embedded systems, software-hardware integration, competition, and working with a team! Our individual small micromouse teams will continue to work on their own maze-solving robots. 

Automated Greenhouse: This project aims to create an autonomous greenhouse that can be used to grow and monitor plants with minimal human intervention. The goal is to keep plants alive and healthy by itself over long periods of time (such as over a winter or summer break). The goal for this year is to create a basic structure that can grow foods such as grape tomatoes and basil. This project is looking for people interested in web development, embedded systems, Internet of Things (IoT), gardening, sustainability, and building! 

 

From Wednesday, November 5, 2025 4:30 PM to 7:30 PM EST at Bonner 416.

The UB YDSA mission is multi-faceted: To educate and organize (primarily) students and young people. To play a helpful and principled role in local movements for social justice. The remaining tasks include completing the electrical work for the batteries and solar panels, installing a bracket for the steering system, adding an emergency shut-off switch, setting up the bilge pump, and making cosmetic modifications to refine the boat’s appearance and functionality. Once complete, the boat will compete in a series of races this summer against other schools.

item.description:

This in-person yoga class consists of yoga postures/movements, meditation, and breath awareness to maintain balance and overall wellness through the challenges of the semester. It is not a fitness class, yet you may choose to test your limits. This class has extended relaxation time at the end. No experience is necessary. All levels are welcome, and all body types and sizes are honored. Dress comfortably. Please bring a towel/yoga mat and a water bottle. If you attend two classes, you can get a free yoga mat! Come every week or drop in when you can. Classes are first come, first serve. Arrive early to get a space in the class. Classes do fill up and may be closed upon arrival.

item.title: Philosophy, Politics, and Economics Club Weekly Meeting
item.description:
Philosophy, Politics, and Economics Club Weekly Meeting

The purpose of the Philosophy, Politics, and Economics (PPE) Club is to provide a space for the open discussion of topics related to the intersection of philosophy, political science, and economics and foster an intellectual community based on mutual respect and curiosity. Join us each week for great conversations about unique topics, lots of fun, and a community like no other on campus (and also pizza).

PPE Club is open to people of all majors and disciplines. Regardless of your background, knowledge of the topics, or future aspirations, PPE Club has something for everyone! PPE Club also serves to connect students with the academic and professional opportunities that are available for those passionate about the humanities and social sciences. Students have made connections through PPE Club that led them to research opportunities, internships, and more. We hope to see you there!

From Thursday, November 6, 2025 5:00 PM to 6:00 PM EST at SU 210 Landmark Room.

item.title: "Navigating Your Way Forward" webinar with UB alum Sharon Ruiz
item.description:
"Navigating Your Way Forward" webinar with UB alum Sharon Ruiz

Abstract: Sharon Ruiz (BSIE/MBA ’85/’86) will recap her journey from graduation to today highlighting the many paths that each WISE student/alumnae can take. She will share some key insights and lessons learned along the way to help you navigate your individual journey in the spirit of “if only I knew then what I know now!” Topics will include the value of relationships, self-awareness, a growth mindset, individual development, mentoring, and keeping a success & learning log. Additionally, she will share the value of learning these lessons/adopting great habits early and continually in your professional career.

 

Bio: Sharon (Garelick) Ruiz is the Vice president of Capacity and Operational Systems at Southeast toyota Distributors, LLC.
A native Buffalonian, Sharon is a graduate of the 3/2 Bachelor of Science in Industrial Engineering/MBA program at SUNY@Buffalo.
After several work experiences in manufacturing and distribution with Corning, Kodak, Simon & Schuster, and Coach in NY and NJ, Sharon relocated for an opportunity with Coach (now Tapestry) to start up a global Distribution and Customer Service Center in Jacksonville, FL. She is mom to Jules, a Junior at the University of Georgia, and Bandit, a 7 year old Sheepadoodle.
In her free time, Sharon is an avid golfer, baker, and loves to travel!

From Thursday, November 6, 2025 6:00 PM to 7:00 PM EST at Online.

Applying to internships, research programs, or jobs in healthcare? Your resume and cover letter are often the first impression you make.

Join AED for a Resume & Cover Letter Writing Workshop designed specifically for pre-health students. In this interactive session, you’ll learn how to:

  • Highlight your clinical, research, and leadership experiences effectively

  • Tailor your resume and cover letter for different opportunities

  • Avoid common mistakes and strengthen your professional presentation

  • Get tips on formatting, phrasing, and standing out in competitive applications

Whether you’re starting from scratch or looking to polish your documents, this workshop will give you the tools and confidence to present your best self on paper.

item.title: UB AIAA November General Body Meeting
item.description:
UB AIAA November General Body Meeting

UB AIAA is an engineering club that offers students hands-on experience with real-world aerospace challenges. The main project is Design/Build/Fly (DBF), an international competition hosted by AIAA, Textron Aviation, and Raytheon. DBF challenges teams to design, build, and fly a custom radio-controlled aircraft that meets a unique set of mission requirements. In addition to DBF, UB AIAA encourages members to grow professionally through participation in AIAA SciTech Forum, AIAA Regional Student Conferences, or Dinner Talks, where students can present research, network with industry professionals, and learn about cutting-edge advancements in aerospace.

In this GBM we will be discussing progress that we have made in the month of October and will be talking about plans towards the initial prototype of the DBF competition plane.

From Thursday, November 6, 2025 7:00 PM to 8:00 PM EST at Nsc 201.
item.author: buffaloaiaa@gmail.com (UB Chapter American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics)
item.host: UB Chapter American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics

item.title: SASE General Body Meeting
item.description:
SASE General Body Meeting

Curious about what SASE is all about? Come learn more about the Society of Asian Scientists and Engineers (SASE) and the wide variety types of events we host throughout the year!

At SASE, we bring together students from all backgrounds to explore interests in science, engineering, and Asian culture. Our events include:

Engineering and Technical Activities: Battle Bots, egg drop and bridge competitions, resume workshops, professional headshots, and LinkedIn profile-building sessions, etc.

Cultural Events: Educational programs highlighting different Asian cultures, We teach and preform traditional dances with our performances, and large-scale celebrations like our hit Lunar New Year Festival from last year.

Social, Mentorship, and Bonding Events: Fun mixers, icebreakers, and opportunities to connect with peers and mentors, like our hit Squid games halloween event from last year, and our hit water festival event, etc.

Community Service: Activities focused on giving back and raising awareness about important issues within our community, like our preparations for the Buffalo science museum showcase, light the night, etc.

Whether you’re looking to grow professionally, learn about Asian cultures, meet new friends, or get involved on campus, learn about opportunities in the STEM field for Asians, SASE has something for you. Join us and be part of our vibrant community!

From Thursday, November 6, 2025 7:00 PM to 9:00 PM EST at Nsc 220.
item.author: ubsase@gmail.com (Society of Asian Scientists & Engineers)

item.title: Pure Monotheism: Understanding Tawheed
item.description:
Pure Monotheism: Understanding Tawheed

“Pure Monotheism: Understanding Tawheed” is an in-depth look at the Islamic belief in the oneness of Allah, known as tawheed. It covers how the early generations of Muslims (the Salaf) understood and explained this core aspect of faith, including its categories, meanings, and relevance to a Muslim’s worship and daily life.

From Thursday, November 6, 2025 6:30 PM to 10:00 PM EST at NSC 225.

item.title: Making Friends at UB: From Hellos to Hangouts
item.description:
Making Friends at UB: From Hellos to Hangouts

Making friends at a large school, like UB, can feel overwhelming—where do you even start? There's no shame in not knowing. This workshop is all about turning those awkward hellos into real hangouts. We’ll talk through the challenges of meeting new people in such a large community and give you simple, practical strategies to connect with your peers. From starting conversations to growing casual acquaintances into genuine friendships, you’ll leave with actionable steps. Whether you’re outgoing, introverted, or somewhere in between, this session will help you feel more confident about building your social circle at UB.

From Friday, November 7, 2025 4:00 PM to 5:00 PM EST at Baldy 111.
item.author: leadub@buffalo.edu (Student Engagement)

The Hardcore Challenge brings together the best of both worlds – pushing your body and mind to new limits. Designed for UB students, this challenge invites participants to go for records in four classic feats: most pushups, most pull-ups, longest planks, and longest dead hang.  

Whether you’re here to set a new personal best or just want to jump in for the fun of it, this event is open to all levels – no prior training required. Come challenge yourself, cheer on your friends, and see what you’re capable of!

item.title: AIAA DBF (Design Build Fly) Build Meeting
item.description:
AIAA DBF (Design Build Fly) Build Meeting

UB AIAA is an engineering club that offers students hands-on experience with real-world aerospace challenges. The main project is Design/Build/Fly (DBF), an international competition hosted by AIAA, Textron Aviation, and Raytheon. DBF challenges teams to design, build, and fly a custom radio-controlled aircraft that meets a unique set of mission requirements. The club holds several meetings throughout the academic year to design and manufacture their RC aircraft. These meetings can range from CADing molds and parts of the plane, running tests to choose the airfoil shape, and hands-on meetings where members can work with carbon fiber or other materials to build the plane.

From Friday, November 7, 2025 6:00 PM to 7:00 PM EST at Furnas Hall, Lab 1025.
item.author: buffaloaiaa@gmail.com (UB Chapter American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics)
item.host: UB Chapter American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics

item.title: IAM3D Project Meeting
item.description:
IAM3D Project Meeting

MONDAYS AND FRIDAYS, 5pm @ Jarvis 305

Welcome to IAM3D! Come learn about CAD, 3D Printing, Electronics, Robotics and 3D Design as we work on our FPV Payload Mars Rover! We will be competing in the Innovative Additive Manufacturing 3D design competition (IAM3D) in April.

Our task is to design and build a first person view mars rover that can pick up different objects and drop them in a bucket, and the challenge is to 3D print as many parts as possible. Join our discord for more info and updates, hope to see you there! ASME discord (Meetings will be in Jarvis 305)

From Friday, November 7, 2025 5:00 PM to 7:45 PM EST at Jarvis 305.

item.title: Social Change Saturday: Veteran's Day of Service
item.description:
Social Change Saturday: Veteran's Day of Service

Volunteer at the Buffalo & Erie County Naval and Military Park to honor Veteran's Day on Saturday, November 8th, from 9:00 AM - 1:00 PM. Transportation will be provided to and from the service site. Learn about and help preserve Buffalo's historical landmarks housed at the Park while speaking with organization representatives and connecting with the community.

Please note that this will be an indoor and outdoor event, so dress and prepare accordingly (i.e. wear warm clothes and prepare for outdoor allergies if needed)!

Social Change Saturdays are off-campus service opportunities for students to volunteer and help serve the local community. This program is meant to encourage students to partner with the surrounding community and increase their sense of social responsibility.

From Saturday, November 8, 2025 9:00 AM to 1:00 PM EST at Meet in 150 Student Union.
