item.title: H2O Sunday Service
item.description:
H2O Sunday Service
 

The purpose of our Sunday Service is to gather together to worship God as a family. We believe that it is not just a meeting, but an opportunity to hear from God through His Word and through others. No matter where you are in your faith journey, you are welcome to join us as you are every Sunday.

You can expect:

  • Authentic worship music so that we may praise Him together
  • Solid Biblical teaching that applies to your life
  • Real stories about what God is doing in people’s lives
  • Conversation and fellowship before and after each gathering

Our Sunday Services are at 10:30am on campus every week! 

From Sunday, November 9, 2025 10:30 AM to 11:45 AM EST at SU 330 Pride & Tradition Assembly Hall.

item.title: "Urinetown The Musical"
item.description:
"Urinetown The Musical"

“Urinetown, The Musical”

Music by Mark Hollman

Book by Greg Kotis

Lyrics by Mark Hollmann and Greg Kotis

Directed and Choreographed by Doug Weyand

Music Direction by Matt Marco

Nov. 6 - 8, 2025 at 7:30 p.m.

Nov.  8 - 9, 2025 at 2 p.m.

UB Center for the Arts Black Box Theatre

Tickets: https://www.ticketmaster.com/search?q=urinetown+ub+center+for+the+arts+black+box

 

$25 Adults | $20 Seniors/Veterans/UB Employees

$15 Students/Children | $10 UB Students

(Ticketmaster fees apply when purchasing online.)

 

A sidesplitting sendup of greed, love, revolution (and musicals!), in a time when water is worth its weight in gold.

 

Winner of three Tony Awards, three Outer Critics Circle Awards, two Lucille Lortel Awards and two Obie Awards, “Urinetown” is a hilarious musical satire of the legal system, capitalism, social irresponsibility, populism, environmental collapse, privatization of natural resources, bureaucracy, municipal politics, and musical theatre itself! Hilariously funny and touchingly honest, Urinetown provides a fresh perspective on one of America's greatest art forms.

 

In a Gotham-like city, a terrible water shortage, caused by a 20-year drought, has led to a government-enforced ban on private toilets. The citizens must use public amenities, regulated by a single malevolent company that profits by charging admission for one of humanity's most basic needs. Amid the people, a hero decides that he's had enough and plans a revolution to lead them all to freedom!

 

Inspired by the works of Bertolt Brecht and Kurt Weill, “Urinetown” is an irreverently humorous satire in which no one is safe from scrutiny. Praised for reinvigorating the very notion of what a musical could be, “Urinetown” catapults the "comedic romp" into the new millennium with its outrageous perspective, wickedly modern wit and sustained ability to produce gales of unbridled laughter.

 

The musical "Urinetown" is rated PG-13, with parental guidance suggested for ages 13 and below due to some humorous adult innuendos and mild profanity.

 

“Urinetown” is presented through special arrangement with Music Theatre International.
www.mtishows.com

The UB Theatre and Dance 2025-2026 season is sponsored in part by Fox Run at Orchard Park, celebrating its seventh year in support of the department.

 

From Thursday, November 6, 2025 7:30 PM to Sunday, November 9, 2025 5:00 PM EST at UB Center for the Arts.

item.description:

UB Badminton Team is going to 2025 YONEX Eastern Collegiate Team Badminton Championships Fall Northern Conferences Division 3 at Boston Badminton.Each conference will have two divisions (1 and 2) if more than 8 teams register and 3 divisions if 15 or more teams register.  Division 1 will comprise the strongest teams. Each team may choose the Division in which they would like to compete. For compelling reasons, the Tournament Director may move a team to a different Division. Northeast Collegiate Teams from MA, NY, CT, RI, NH, ME, VT shall play in the Northern Conference while Teams from NJ, PA, DE, MD, DC and VA shall play in the MidAtlantic Conference.

From Saturday, November 8, 2025 7:00 AM to Sunday, November 9, 2025 6:00 PM EST at Boston Badminton.

item.title: ESW Precious Plastics Project
item.description:
ESW Precious Plastics Project

Did you know that a lot of the cheap plastic bottles you recycle go to the landfill anyways? Our Precious Plastics project aims to mitigate harmful plastic waste by compacting those low-quality plastics into energy-efficient building materials (eco-bricks)!

Join us in using engineering and material concepts to construct our very own plastic eco-bricks.

No prior knowledge is needed, this project is open to students of every discipline!

For more information and updates check out our socials

Instagram: https://www.instagram.com/esw_ub/

Discord: https://discord.gg/w2BN2Ju3

MONDAYS AND FRIDAYS, 5pm @ Jarvis 305

Welcome to IAM3D! Come learn about CAD, 3D Printing, Electronics, Robotics and 3D Design as we work on our FPV Payload Mars Rover! We will be competing in the Innovative Additive Manufacturing 3D design competition (IAM3D) in April.

Our task is to design and build a first person view mars rover that can pick up different objects and drop them in a bucket, and the challenge is to 3D print as many parts as possible. Join our discord for more info and updates, hope to see you there! ASME discord (Meetings will be in Jarvis 305)

item.title: BASIC Weekly Meeting
item.description:
BASIC Weekly Meeting

Every Monday night our club meet for our weekly meetings. At these meetings, we start at 8:00 pm with worship songs followed by prayer and announcements. Each week we have a different speaker come and give a message relevant to the theme of the semester. They are introduced after announcements to give there 15–30-minute message. After the message men and women break up into small groups to further discuss the message. These small groups are a time to discuss the message and how it is relevant in our lives. Then we close in prayer for any student needs or general issues going on and the night ends with everyone enjoying a time of fellowship and catching up with new and old friends. 

From Monday, November 10, 2025 8:00 PM to 9:30 PM EST at SU 145 A+F+B+E.

GIM #10: FASA Family Feud!

item.title: Diverse Donor Drive: NMDP UB √ó ŒõŒ¶Œï √ó Œ±ŒöŒîŒ¶
item.description:
Diverse Donor Drive: NMDP UB √ó ŒõŒ¶Œï √ó Œ±ŒöŒîŒ¶

Join the NMDP Chapter of UB for a special marrow‚Äëdonor drive in partnership with Lambda Phi Epsilon and Alpha Kappa Delta Phi. A blood stem‚Äëcell transplant can treat more than 75 different blood cancers and disorders, but roughly 70‚ÄØ% of patients can’t find a match within their own family. Because genetic markers are tied to ancestry, under‚Äërepresented groups face especially long odds.

At our table you’ll learn how a simple cheek swab enrolls you in the NMDP registry and what happens if you’re ever matched. Members of ΛΦΕ and αΚΔΦ will be on hand to share why diverse donors are critical and to answer your questions. Whether you’re ready to register or just curious about volunteering, stop by to discover how five minutes of your time could give someone a second chance at life.

From Tuesday, November 11, 2025 12:00 PM to 4:00 PM EST at Knox Table.

item.title: Solar Splash Meeting
item.description:
Solar Splash Meeting

The American Society of Mechanical Engineers presents: 

Solar Splash

The Solar Splash project is a solar-powered motorboat that combines renewable energy with efficient design. The remaining tasks include completing the electrical work for the batteries and solar panels, installing a bracket for the steering system, adding an emergency shut-off switch, setting up the bilge pump, and making cosmetic modifications to refine the boat’s appearance and functionality. Once complete, the boat will compete in a series of races this summer against other schools.

item.title: Graduate Christian Fellowship (Cancelled)
item.description:
Graduate Christian Fellowship

The Graduate Christian Fellowship (GCF) at UB is a welcoming community of graduate students, professional students, and post-docs who are curious about Jesus and what his life, death, and resurrection mean for our work and for the world.

 

This semester, we are reading the book of Colossians, a letter that invites us to see all of life (our studies, our relationships, our work, and our world) through the lens of Christ. Written to a young community learning to follow Jesus in a complex cultural moment, Colossians speaks with surprising clarity to our own questions of identity, purpose, and hope.

From Tuesday, November 11, 2025 7:00 PM to 8:30 PM EST at Online.

item.title: ASC Region 1 Competition Training
item.description:
ASC Region 1 Competition Training

The Region 1 ASC Competition Training is designed to prepare student teams for the Associated Schools of Construction (ASC) Region 1 Competition. This training provides participants with hands-on experience, industry insights, and practical guidance to strengthen their skills in estimating, scheduling, project management, and team collaboration.

Through a series of workshops, mock problems, and mentorship from industry professionals, students will gain a deeper understanding of real-world construction scenarios and competition expectations. The training emphasizes technical accuracy, time management, and effective communication—key components for success at the ASC competition.

This preparation ensures teams are well-equipped to perform under pressure and represent their schools with confidence and professionalism at the regional level.

From Tuesday, November 11, 2025 6:30 PM to 8:30 PM EST at Cooke 127B.

item.title: Geography Graduate Students Writing Group
item.description:
Geography Graduate Students Writing Group

The graduate students' writing workshop is a place for graduate students in the Geography department to write together. This workshop lasts for two hours every week, where students have a focused time to write academic materials, like drafts of research papers, research proposals, dissertations, course assignments, or any other writing. Besides writing, you can also do other research work, like reading papers and analyzing data. This workshop has two main goals: (1) improve the productivity of students, and (2) to learn about the research work of peers. It is hybrid, so you can join in person or remotely. 

 

All attendees must review the GSA Safety Acknowledgement – Participation Disclaimer – Graduate Student Association before attending. 

From Wednesday, November 12, 2025 10:00 AM to 12:00 PM EST at Graduate Lounge, 401 Wilkeson Quad.

item.description:
Yoga for Beginners with Jackie
This class is for every person who "isn't flexible", "doesn't have good balance", and "can't sit still". Come find your body's expression of yoga! This in-person yoga class is for EVERYONE! Classes will consist of movements that focus on functional range of motion and provide an introduction to yoga postures. Options for modifications or deepening of postures will be included. Breath awareness and meditation will be introduced as the semester progresses.
 
No experience is necessary, please come dressed comfortably. Please bring a yoga mat or towel, and a water bottle. All other props will be provided. Classes are first-come, first-served. Please arrive early to get a space and set up. Classes do fill up and may be closed.

item.title: Being NOBULL: Putting Bystander Intervention into Action
item.description:
Being NOBULL: Putting Bystander Intervention into Action

LIVE YOUR VALUES! Have you intervened in a situation to keep someone from being hurt or harmed? Why did you act instead of standing by? Chances are it is because it is in line with one of your personal values. Even though we all have a set of personal values, we do not always have the chance to our values. Let’s talk about ways to overcome the barriers to intervening and how to refine the skills you already have at Being NOBULL- Putting Bystander Intervention into Action. At the end of this program, participants will be able to: identify personal barriers to intervening, identify personal reasons for intervening, articulate their personal bystander intervention style and will begin developing plans for intervening if they see someone who needs help.

From Wednesday, November 12, 2025 4:00 PM to 5:30 PM EST at 235 Student Union.

item.title: IEEE Micromouse and Automated Greenhouse Project Meeting
item.description:
IEEE Micromouse and Automated Greenhouse Project Meeting

IEEE will be hosting the weekly meeting for Micromouse and Automated Greenhouse during this meeting time. 

Micromouse: Build an autonomous maze solving robot and compete against others! UB IEEE targets the annual Region 1 and 2 Micromouse Student Competition and annual Applied Power and Electronics (APEC) Micromouse Competition. This is a great opportunity for those who love embedded systems, software-hardware integration, competition, and working with a team! Our individual small micromouse teams will continue to work on their own maze-solving robots. 

Automated Greenhouse: This project aims to create an autonomous greenhouse that can be used to grow and monitor plants with minimal human intervention. The goal is to keep plants alive and healthy by itself over long periods of time (such as over a winter or summer break). The goal for this year is to create a basic structure that can grow foods such as grape tomatoes and basil. This project is looking for people interested in web development, embedded systems, Internet of Things (IoT), gardening, sustainability, and building! 

 

From Wednesday, November 12, 2025 4:30 PM to 7:30 PM EST at Bonner 416.

item.description:
Leadership by Design: Lead with Your Strengths

DISC assessments are used to improve productivity, communication, and teamwork. DiSCover your DiSC profile, boost your efficiency and build strong relationships. The workshop will discuss the principles behind DiSC and will help attendees examine their own communication style and will provide techniques on how to communicate more effectively with others. 

This assessment normally costs $30, but is FREE to you as a UB student! Take advantage of this opportunity. Learn more about your motivators, strengths, how you communicate, how you work on a team. DISC will give you tips on how to best work with others.

You MUST complete the RSVP by 10/21 pr 11/6 to receive the assessment code to get the link to complete the assessment and have your report compiled before the workshop.

REQUIRED Workshop to complete the Organizational Development Badge!

The American Society of Mechanical Engineers presents: 

Solar Splash

The Solar Splash project is a solar-powered motorboat that combines renewable energy with efficient design. The remaining tasks include completing the electrical work for the batteries and solar panels, installing a bracket for the steering system, adding an emergency shut-off switch, setting up the bilge pump, and making cosmetic modifications to refine the boat’s appearance and functionality. This in-person yoga class consists of yoga postures/movements, meditation, and breath awareness to maintain balance and overall wellness through the challenges of the semester. It is not a fitness class, yet you may choose to test your limits. This class has extended relaxation time at the end. No experience is necessary. All levels are welcome, and all body types and sizes are honored. Dress comfortably. Please bring a towel/yoga mat and a water bottle. If you attend two classes, you can get a free yoga mat! Come every week or drop in when you can. Classes are first come, first serve. Arrive early to get a space in the class. Classes do fill up and may be closed upon arrival.

item.description:
Philosophy, Politics, and Economics Club Weekly Meeting

The purpose of the Philosophy, Politics, and Economics (PPE) Club is to provide a space for the open discussion of topics related to the intersection of philosophy, political science, and economics and foster an intellectual community based on mutual respect and curiosity. Join us each week for great conversations about unique topics, lots of fun, and a community like no other on campus (and also pizza).

PPE Club is open to people of all majors and disciplines. Regardless of your background, knowledge of the topics, or future aspirations, PPE Club has something for everyone! PPE Club also serves to connect students with the academic and professional opportunities that are available for those passionate about the humanities and social sciences. Students have made connections through PPE Club that led them to research opportunities, internships, and more. We hope to see you there!

From Thursday, November 13, 2025 5:00 PM to 6:00 PM EST at SU 210 Landmark Room.

item.title: Bonding Across NeuroDiversity: A Neurodiversity Social Gathering
item.description:
Bonding Across NeuroDiversity: A Neurodiversity Social Gathering

Join Accessibility Resources and UB Counseling Services to connect, relax, and celebrate the strengths of our neurodiverse community! item.title: Pure Monotheism: Understanding Tawheed
item.description:
Pure Monotheism: Understanding Tawheed

“Pure Monotheism: Understanding Tawheed” is an in-depth look at the Islamic belief in the oneness of Allah, known as tawheed. It covers how the early generations of Muslims (the Salaf) understood and explained this core aspect of faith, including its categories, meanings, and relevance to a Muslim’s worship and daily life.

From Thursday, November 13, 2025 5:00 PM to 8:30 PM EST at O'Brian 112.

Take time to relax with us and partake in the appreciation of this practice as we learn about the ethnic groups that use it and its religious and artistic uses! Sand painting as an art form is a painting that is created by using finely crushed materials that are typically applied to plywood or colorful sand, to canvases, to depict a scene.

item.title: SASE General Body Meeting
item.description:
SASE General Body Meeting

Curious about what SASE is all about? Come learn more about the Society of Asian Scientists and Engineers (SASE) and the wide variety types of events we host throughout the year!

At SASE, we bring together students from all backgrounds to explore interests in science, engineering, and Asian culture. Our events include:

Engineering and Technical Activities: Battle Bots, egg drop and bridge competitions, resume workshops, professional headshots, and LinkedIn profile-building sessions, etc.

Cultural Events: Educational programs highlighting different Asian cultures, We teach and preform traditional dances with our performances, and large-scale celebrations like our hit Lunar New Year Festival from last year.

Social, Mentorship, and Bonding Events: Fun mixers, icebreakers, and opportunities to connect with peers and mentors, like our hit Squid games halloween event from last year, and our hit water festival event, etc.

Community Service: Activities focused on giving back and raising awareness about important issues within our community, like our preparations for the Buffalo science museum showcase, light the night, etc.

Whether you’re looking to grow professionally, learn about Asian cultures, meet new friends, or get involved on campus, learn about opportunities in the STEM field for Asians, SASE has something for you. Join us and be part of our vibrant community!

From Thursday, November 13, 2025 7:00 PM to 9:00 PM EST at Knox 04.

item.description:
The Hardcore Challenge

Ready to take on the ultimate test of strength and endurance?  

The Hardcore Challenge brings together the best of both worlds – pushing your body and mind to new limits. Designed for UB students, this challenge invites participants to go for records in four classic feats: most pushups, most pull-ups, longest planks, and longest dead hang.  

Whether you’re here to set a new personal best or just want to jump in for the fun of it, this event is open to all levels – no prior training required. Come challenge yourself, cheer on your friends, and see what you’re capable of!

item.title: AIAA DBF (Design Build Fly) Build Meeting
item.description:
AIAA DBF (Design Build Fly) Build Meeting

UB AIAA is an engineering club that offers students hands-on experience with real-world aerospace challenges. The main project is Design/Build/Fly (DBF), an international competition hosted by AIAA, Textron Aviation, and Raytheon. DBF challenges teams to design, build, and fly a custom radio-controlled aircraft that meets a unique set of mission requirements. The club holds several meetings throughout the academic year to design and manufacture their RC aircraft. These meetings can range from CADing molds and parts of the plane, running tests to choose the airfoil shape, and hands-on meetings where members can work with carbon fiber or other materials to build the plane.

From Friday, November 14, 2025 6:00 PM to 7:00 PM EST at Furnas Hall, Lab 1025.
item.author: buffaloaiaa@gmail.com (UB Chapter American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics)
item.host: UB Chapter American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics

item.title: IAM3D Project Meeting
item.description:
IAM3D Project Meeting

MONDAYS AND FRIDAYS, 5pm @ Jarvis 305

Welcome to IAM3D! Come learn about CAD, 3D Printing, Electronics, Robotics and 3D Design as we work on our FPV Payload Mars Rover! We will be competing in the Innovative Additive Manufacturing 3D design competition (IAM3D) in April.

Our task is to design and build a first person view mars rover that can pick up different objects and drop them in a bucket, and the challenge is to 3D print as many parts as possible. Join our discord for more info and updates, hope to see you there! ASME discord (Meetings will be in Jarvis 305)

From Friday, November 14, 2025 5:00 PM to 7:45 PM EST at Jarvis 305.

item.title: Unplug and Play
item.description:
Unplug and Play

A program for students, by students, Unplug & Play brings you all the feels of family game night with some life-sized additions. UB Rec & the Bulls Team Shop have teamed up to offer UB Students a weekly night of fun, games, popcorn, music and major shopping sales!

Discover a refreshing and tech-free approach to fun at UB Recreation with our Unplug & Play program! Enjoy inclusive, low-stress activities featuring giant games like Jenga, Corn Hole, and Connect-4, accessible to all skill levels. Experience classic and giant games like chess, checkers, ping-pong, and Yahtzee, along with creative activities like coloring pages, ensuring everyone has a well-rounded and enjoyable time.

UB Students, don't miss out! Enjoy 20% OFF at the Bulls Team Shop every Friday* from 5pm - 8pm in Alumni Arena. Join us for fun and games!

*Unplug & Play programming is only available during the fall and spring semester. Hours are Subject to Change.

More info: https://www.buffalo.edu/recreation/we-have-fun/open-rec--programs/unplug-and-play.html

 

From Friday, November 14, 2025 5:00 PM to 8:00 PM EST at Alumni Arena .
item.author: ub-recreation@buffalo.edu (UB Rec)

item.title: Mock Gaye Holud 2025
item.description:
Mock Gaye Holud 2025

Mock Gaye Holud 2025, a fun and festive twist on the traditional Bangladeshi pre-wedding ceremony.

Experience the beauty of Bangladeshi culture through colorful decorations, lively music, vibrant dances, and playful wedding rituals — all wrapped in laughter and community spirit. The event will showcase the warmth of our traditions, from turmeric blessings to dazzling performances, and of course, plenty of delicious food!

Come dressed in your best traditional Bangladeshi/South Asian attire and celebrate with us. Let’s make this night unforgettable!

From Saturday, November 15, 2025 6:30 PM to 11:00 PM EST at Templeton Landing Restaurant & Special Events.

item.title: ASC Region 1 Competition
item.description:
ASC Region 1 Competition

The "ASC competition" can refer to two distinct annual events: the Associated Schools of Construction (ASC) Student Competition for construction management students and the ASC Student Supercomputer Challenge for high-performance computing (HPC). This event challenges construction management students to apply their knowledge to real-world construction project problems provided by industry professionals. 

From Thursday, November 13, 2025 9:00 AM to Sunday, November 16, 2025 12:00 AM EST at Hilton Albany.

item.title: H2O Sunday Service
item.description:
H2O Sunday Service
 

The purpose of our Sunday Service is to gather together to worship God as a family. We believe that it is not just a meeting, but an opportunity to hear from God through His Word and through others. No matter where you are in your faith journey, you are welcome to join us as you are every Sunday.

You can expect:

  • Authentic worship music so that we may praise Him together
  • Solid Biblical teaching that applies to your life
  • Real stories about what God is doing in people’s lives
  • Conversation and fellowship before and after each gathering

Our Sunday Services are at 10:30am on campus every week! 

From Sunday, November 16, 2025 10:30 AM to 11:45 AM EST at SU 330 Pride & Tradition Assembly Hall.
item.author: h2ochurchbuffalo@gmail.com (H2O Church)

item.title: BASICON Fall 26
item.description:
BASICON Fall 26

Join hundreds of college students and young adults for a weekend of passionate worship, dynamic teaching and life-changing ministry! This high energy event is one of the largest of its kind in the Northeast, drawing students from dozens of universities and churches.

BASICCON is the biannual conference (spring and fall) for BASIC College Ministries.

BASICCON will be held November 14-16th at the Hyatt Regency in Downtown Rochester. Join us for a live in person event with worship, teaching and workshops. 

From Friday, November 14, 2025 7:45 PM to Sunday, November 16, 2025 12:00 PM EST at Wyndham Hotel Downtown Rochester.

item.host: Brothers and Sisters in Christ at UB

This high energy event is one of the largest of its kind in the Northeast, drawing students from dozens of universities and churches. item.title: UB Badminton Open Play
item.description:
UB Badminton Open Play

UB Badminton hosts a weekly open play session every Sunday from 11 AM to 2 PM at the Triple Gym Alumni Arena. Players of all skill levels are welcome to join. We have 8 courts available, and we provide rackets and used birdies. The back 4 courts have a 20-minute rotation, while the front 4 courts operate on a waitlist system, allowing players up to 2 sets of games.

Please remember to bring your UBLINKED event pass for check-in. If you need to borrow a racket, be sure to bring your ID for rental. We look forward to seeing you on Sundays and hope you have a fantastic time at our open play session!

From Sunday, November 16, 2025 11:00 AM to 2:00 PM EST at Triple Gym, Alumni Arena.
item.author: team.ub2023@gmail.com (Badminton Club)

item.title: Choreographers Showcase
item.description:
Choreographers Showcase

Choreographers Showcase

Directed by Chanon Judson with Rebekah Bono and Charity John

Nov. 14 - 15, 2025 at 7:30 p.m.

Nov. 15 - 16, 2025 at 2 p.m.

UB Center for the Arts Drama Theatre

Tickets: https://www.ticketmaster.com/search?q=choreographers+showcase+ub+center+for+the+arts

 

$25 Adults | $20 Seniors/Veterans/UB Employees

$15 Students/Children | $10 UB Students

(Ticketmaster fees apply when purchasing online.)

 

Celebrating diversity in both genre and theme, Choreographers Showcase features new dance works created and performed by BA, BFA and MFA dance majors. Student choreographers receive close faculty mentorship and collaborate with student lighting designers, sound designers, costumers and technicians.

 

The UB Theatre and Dance 2025-2026 season is sponsored in part by Fox Run at Orchard Park, celebrating its seventh year in support of the department.

From Friday, November 14, 2025 7:30 PM to Sunday, November 16, 2025 4:30 PM EST at UB Center for the Arts.

item.title: Community Assistant Information Session
item.description:
Community Assistant Information Session
Come to an Information Session to learn more about the Community Assistant (CA) position for the 2026–2027 academic year at the University at Buffalo! This session will cover everything you need to know about the role, including responsibilities, renumeration, and how to apply. Being a CA is a great opportunity to build leadership skills, connect with the campus community, and make a positive impact in UB’s residence halls and apartments. Whether you're seriously considering applying or just want to explore your options, this session is a great place to start!
 
The Community Assistant (CA) is previously known as Resident Assistant (RA) and Academic Assistant (AA).

From Monday, November 17, 2025 12:00 PM to 1:00 PM EST at 210 Student Union.

All bodies and abilities are welcome… practice on a yoga mat, in a chair, or wheelchair. Whatever works for you! No previous experience necessary and props will be provided. item.title: ESW Precious Plastics Project
item.description:
ESW Precious Plastics Project

Did you know that a lot of the cheap plastic bottles you recycle go to the landfill anyways? Our Precious Plastics project aims to mitigate harmful plastic waste by compacting those low-quality plastics into energy-efficient building materials (eco-bricks)!

Join us in using engineering and material concepts to construct our very own plastic eco-bricks.

No prior knowledge is needed, this project is open to students of every discipline!

For more information and updates check out our socials

Instagram: https://www.instagram.com/esw_ub/

Discord: https://discord.gg/w2BN2Ju3

From Monday, November 17, 2025 6:00 PM to 7:00 PM EST at Clemens 06.

item.title: IAM3D Project Meeting
item.description:
IAM3D Project Meeting

MONDAYS AND FRIDAYS, 5pm @ Jarvis 305

Welcome to IAM3D! Come learn about CAD, 3D Printing, Electronics, Robotics and 3D Design as we work on our FPV Payload Mars Rover! We will be competing in the Innovative Additive Manufacturing 3D design competition (IAM3D) in April.

Our task is to design and build a first person view mars rover that can pick up different objects and drop them in a bucket, and the challenge is to 3D print as many parts as possible. Join our discord for more info and updates, hope to see you there! ASME discord (Meetings will be in Jarvis 305)

From Monday, November 17, 2025 5:00 PM to 7:45 PM EST at Jarvis 305.

item.title: WHWA Event #2
item.description:
WHWA Event #2

The WHWA is an on-campus organization dedicated to promoting and advocating for the equitable healthcare and overall wellness of all women. This includes educating our community about various topics that we discuss at our general body meetings such as sexual wellness, domestic violence awareness, types of contraception methods, mental health resources, diseases & disorders that disproportionately impact women, etc. We are committed to empowering women from all backgrounds, cultures, and gender identities with holistic health information. We encourage everyone to join us to learn about and discuss various topics surrounding women's health.

We’ll also take a moment to celebrate all the hard work and involvement from our members this semester. As finals approach, we want to wish you the best of luck and encourage you to take care of yourselves during this busy time.

We’ll close the meeting with a warm send-off—enjoy the upcoming holidays, and we look forward to seeing everyone back next semester!

item.description:
Feeling Your Yoga: Tuesdays with Cory
This in-person yoga class consists of yoga postures/movements, meditation, and breath awareness to maintain balance and overall wellness through the challenges of the semester. It is not a fitness class, yet you may choose to test your limits. This class has extended relaxation time at the end. No experience is necessary. All levels are welcome, and all body types and sizes are honored. Dress comfortably. Please bring a towel/yoga mat and a water bottle. If you attend two classes, you can get a free yoga mat! Come every week or drop in when you can. Classes are first come, first serve. Arrive early to get a space in the class. Classes do fill up and may be closed upon arrival.

item.description:

Life Groups exist so that we can gather together and study God’s Word in more intimate settings. We have 2 different Life Groups to meet the needs of your busy students schedules! This Life Group meets on Tuesday nights, but if you aren't available Tuesday's we also have a Wednesday Life Group! Life Groups are an essential weekly rhythm for H2O as they provide opportunity to know others and be known. You can expect to Study God’s Word, pray together, and be a part of a family who loves God together. Whether you’ve been in church your whole life or haven’t ever been, you are welcome to join us at Life Group.

item.title: Graduate Christian Fellowship (Cancelled)
item.description:
Graduate Christian Fellowship

The Graduate Christian Fellowship (GCF) at UB is a welcoming community of graduate students, professional students, and post-docs who are curious about Jesus and what his life, death, and resurrection mean for our work and for the world.

 

This semester, we are reading the book of Colossians, a letter that invites us to see all of life (our studies, our relationships, our work, and our world) through the lens of Christ. Written to a young community learning to follow Jesus in a complex cultural moment, Colossians speaks with surprising clarity to our own questions of identity, purpose, and hope.

From Tuesday, November 18, 2025 7:00 PM to 8:30 PM EST at Online.
item.author: chris.sullivan@intervarsity.org (Intervarsity Christian Fellowship)

item.title: Geography Graduate Students Writing Group
item.description:
Geography Graduate Students Writing Group

The graduate students' writing workshop is a place for graduate students in the Geography department to write together. This workshop lasts for two hours every week, where students have a focused time to write academic materials, like drafts of research papers, research proposals, dissertations, course assignments, or any other writing. Besides writing, you can also do other research work, like reading papers and analyzing data. This workshop has two main goals: (1) improve the productivity of students, and (2) to learn about the research work of peers. It is hybrid, so you can join in person or remotely. 

 

All attendees must review the GSA Safety Acknowledgement – Participation Disclaimer – Graduate Student Association before attending. 

From Wednesday, November 19, 2025 10:00 AM to 12:00 PM EST at Graduate Lounge, 401 Wilkeson Quad.

item.title: IEEE Micromouse and Automated Greenhouse Project Meeting
item.description:
IEEE Micromouse and Automated Greenhouse Project Meeting

IEEE will be hosting the weekly meeting for Micromouse and Automated Greenhouse during this meeting time. 

Micromouse: Build an autonomous maze solving robot and compete against others! UB IEEE targets the annual Region 1 and 2 Micromouse Student Competition and annual Applied Power and Electronics (APEC) Micromouse Competition. This is a great opportunity for those who love embedded systems, software-hardware integration, competition, and working with a team! Our individual small micromouse teams will continue to work on their own maze-solving robots. 

Automated Greenhouse: This project aims to create an autonomous greenhouse that can be used to grow and monitor plants with minimal human intervention. The goal is to keep plants alive and healthy by itself over long periods of time (such as over a winter or summer break). The goal for this year is to create a basic structure that can grow foods such as grape tomatoes and basil. This project is looking for people interested in web development, embedded systems, Internet of Things (IoT), gardening, sustainability, and building! 

 

From Wednesday, November 19, 2025 4:30 PM to 7:30 PM EST at Bonner 416.

item.title: Hands Only CPR Training - BMES x Phi Sigma Rho
item.description:
Hands Only CPR Training - BMES x Phi Sigma Rho

Hands-Only CPR Training with BMES & Phi Sigma Rho


Join the Biomedical Engineering Society (BMES) and Phi Sigma Rho for a life-saving workshop led by 2024 Woman of Impact Winner Kathy Lovett-McKeever, a certified CPR trainer and passionate advocate for CPR training and cardiovascular health.

In this interactive event, participants will learn Hands-Only CPR—a quick, effective technique that can double or triple a person’s chance of survival during sudden cardiac arrest. Kathy will provide hands-on guidance in proper technique, share her expertise as a trainer, and highlight the vital role CPR plays in saving lives and advancing women’s heart health.

Don’t miss this opportunity to gain confidence in responding to cardiac emergencies and to learn directly from a Woman of Impact honoree making a difference in our community!

From Wednesday, November 19, 2025 6:00 PM to 8:00 PM EST at Bonner 414.

item.title: APhA Patient Counseling Competition
item.description:
APhA Patient Counseling Competition

If you enjoy applying your knowledge of pharmacy and want a fun way to practice these skills, then the annual APhA-ASP National Patient Counseling Competition is for you!

All student levels, P1-P4 (members and non-members), are invited and encouraged to participate. For those P4s that are interested we can make accommodations to allow you to compete virtually if you are not in the Buffalo area. The counseling competition starts at the local level here at UB, and there are a total of two rounds. Both rounds are run similarly to the counseling sessions that you complete in your Patient Care Essentials classes. The preliminary round includes a basic prescription that you, as the student pharmacist, have to counsel a mock patient on. You will receive time to review any drug database of your choosing to prepare what you would like to convey to the patient, similar to a real-life scenario.

Please note that you do not need extensive clinical knowledge to compete in this competition! The goal of this is to practice how you convey information to a patient and how you utilize your communication skills. From the preliminary round, the top ten students chosen by our pharmacist judges will move on to the final round here at UB. The final round will be run very similarly to the first round; however, it will be more challenging. The winner of the final round will have the chance of representing the University at Buffalo School of Pharmacy and Pharmaceutical Sciences at the APhA annual meeting by competing in a virtual preliminary round. If the
winner makes it past the virtual round, they will get to compete against other students from all over the country! The top ten finalists in the national competition will get recognized during the awards celebration at the annual meeting and even receive cash prizes!

This is a great way to practice counseling without a formal grade for a class, allowing you to just have a conversation with a patient! Both rounds will be held in the patient assessment room, so it should feel very familiar to what you have already been doing in your classes. Each round will be recorded as well, so there is
no pressure of judges watching you as you counsel.

From Thursday, November 20, 2025 3:00 PM to 4:00 PM EST at PB 250.
item.author: aphaaspub@gmail.com (American Pharmacists Association- Academy of Student Pharmacists UB Chapter)
item.host: American Pharmacists Association- Academy of Student Pharmacists UB Chapter

item.description:
Yoga for Student Well-being: Thursdays with Tara
This in-person yoga class consists of yoga postures/movements, meditation, and breath awareness to maintain balance and overall wellness through the challenges of the semester. It is not a fitness class, yet you may choose to test your limits. This class has extended relaxation time at the end. No experience is necessary. All levels are welcome, and all body types and sizes are honored. Dress comfortably. Please bring a towel/yoga mat and a water bottle. If you attend two classes, you can get a free yoga mat! Come every week or drop in when you can. Classes are first come, first serve. Arrive early to get a space in the class. Classes do fill up and may be closed upon arrival.

This workshop will introduce students, staff, and faculty to the principles and practices of coalition-building in civic and community contexts. The session will explore how diverse groups can work together across lines of difference to advance shared goals. Through focusing on a local real-world example, interactive activities, and small-group dialogue, participants will gain tools to build trust, create collaboration, and navigate challenges in collective action for change.

item.title: Philosophy, Politics, and Economics Club Weekly Meeting
item.description:
Philosophy, Politics, and Economics Club Weekly Meeting

The purpose of the Philosophy, Politics, and Economics (PPE) Club is to provide a space for the open discussion of topics related to the intersection of philosophy, political science, and economics and foster an intellectual community based on mutual respect and curiosity. Join us each week for great conversations about unique topics, lots of fun, and a community like no other on campus (and also pizza).

PPE Club is open to people of all majors and disciplines. Regardless of your background, knowledge of the topics, or future aspirations, PPE Club has something for everyone! PPE Club also serves to connect students with the academic and professional opportunities that are available for those passionate about the humanities and social sciences. Students have made connections through PPE Club that led them to research opportunities, internships, and more. We hope to see you there!

From Thursday, November 20, 2025 5:00 PM to 6:00 PM EST at SU 210 Landmark Room.

item.title: Telling Your Science Story: A Workshop for Non-Native English Speakers
item.description:
Telling Your Science Story: A Workshop for Non-Native English Speakers

This 4 hour intensive workshop is designed to assist participants in communicating their science to broad audiences. Participants will analyze example components of effective storytelling about scientific research, frame their ideas to tell their own story, practice telling their story to peers, and give and receive feedback on their story. The facilitators will review best practices when discussing one’s research to a broad audience and the various pitfalls postdocs and scholars might encounter as they communicate outside of their lab.

Included topics:

  • The importance of and framing research for both scientific and non-scientific audiences
  • English language and rhetoric of storytelling
  • Use of analogies
  • Hooking the audience – making the story interesting and memorable
  • Organizing the story – a 4-step approach
  • Strategies and components of effective delivery

 

This session is intended for PhD students and Postdoctoral Scholars only. Seating is limited to 50 participants, and pre-registration is required. Light refreshments will be provided.

Register for Telling Your Science Story: A Workshop for Non-Native English Speakers.

From Friday, November 21, 2025 12:00 PM to 4:00 PM EST at 305 Capen Hall (Silverman Library, North Campus).

item.title: AIAA DBF (Design Build Fly) Build Meeting
item.description:
AIAA DBF (Design Build Fly) Build Meeting

UB AIAA is an engineering club that offers students hands-on experience with real-world aerospace challenges. The main project is Design/Build/Fly (DBF), an international competition hosted by AIAA, Textron Aviation, and Raytheon. DBF challenges teams to design, build, and fly a custom radio-controlled aircraft that meets a unique set of mission requirements. The club holds several meetings throughout the academic year to design and manufacture their RC aircraft. These meetings can range from CADing molds and parts of the plane, running tests to choose the airfoil shape, and hands-on meetings where members can work with carbon fiber or other materials to build the plane.

From Friday, November 21, 2025 6:00 PM to 7:00 PM EST at Furnas Hall, Lab 1025.

item.title: IAM3D Project Meeting
item.description:
IAM3D Project Meeting

MONDAYS AND FRIDAYS, 5pm @ Jarvis 305

Welcome to IAM3D! Come learn about CAD, 3D Printing, Electronics, Robotics and 3D Design as we work on our FPV Payload Mars Rover! We will be competing in the Innovative Additive Manufacturing 3D design competition (IAM3D) in April.

Our task is to design and build a first person view mars rover that can pick up different objects and drop them in a bucket, and the challenge is to 3D print as many parts as possible. Join our discord for more info and updates, hope to see you there! ASME discord (Meetings will be in Jarvis 305)

From Friday, November 21, 2025 5:00 PM to 7:45 PM EST at Jarvis 305.

item.title: Unplug and Play
item.description:
Unplug and Play

A program for students, by students, Unplug & Play brings you all the feels of family game night with some life-sized additions. UB Rec & the Bulls Team Shop have teamed up to offer UB Students a weekly night of fun, games, popcorn, music and major shopping sales!

Discover a refreshing and tech-free approach to fun at UB Recreation with our Unplug & Play program! Enjoy inclusive, low-stress activities featuring giant games like Jenga, Corn Hole, and Connect-4, accessible to all skill levels. Experience classic and giant games like chess, checkers, ping-pong, and Yahtzee, along with creative activities like coloring pages, ensuring everyone has a well-rounded and enjoyable time.

UB Students, don't miss out! Enjoy 20% OFF at the Bulls Team Shop every Friday* from 5pm - 8pm in Alumni Arena. Join us for fun and games!

*Unplug & Play programming is only available during the fall and spring semester. Hours are Subject to Change.

More info: https://www.buffalo.edu/recreation/we-have-fun/open-rec--programs/unplug-and-play.html

 

From Friday, November 21, 2025 5:00 PM to 8:00 PM EST at Alumni Arena .

item.title: UBMT Sings: Ahrens & Flaherty in Concert
item.description:
UBMT Sings: Ahrens & Flaherty in Concert

UBMT Sings: Ahrens & Flaherty in Concert

Music by Lynn Ahrens and Stephen Flaherty

Directed by James Beaudry

Music Direction by Matt Marco

Nov. 22, 2025 at 7:30 p.m.

UB Katharine Cornell Theatre

Tickets: https://www.ticketmaster.com/event/000062E7B6DD6CCA

 

$25 Adults | $20 Seniors/Veterans/UB Employees

$15 Students/Children | $10 UB Students

(Ticketmaster fees apply when purchasing online.)

 

The third annual UBMT Sings concert will feature BFA Music Theatre students performing the songs of one of the greatest writing teams in Broadway history. Lynn Ahrens and Stephen Flaherty are, respectively, the lyricist and composer behind “Ragtime,” “Once on This Island,” “Seussical,” “Anastasia,” and more. These renowned collaborators have received theater, film and music’s highest honors—the Tony Award, Drama Desk, Outer Critics Circle and Olivier Awards, as well as nominations for two Academy Awards, two Golden Globes and four Grammys. Join our students as they explore the rich melodies and beautifully drawn characters that defined a generation of musical theatre.

 

The UB Theatre and Dance 2025-2026 season is sponsored in part by Fox Run at Orchard Park, celebrating its seventh year in support of the department.

From Saturday, November 22, 2025 7:30 PM to 9:30 PM EST at Katharine Cornell Theatre.
item.author: rjf3@buffalo.edu (Department of Theatre and Dance)

item.description:

The purpose of our Sunday Service is to gather together to worship God as a family. We believe that it is not just a meeting, but an opportunity to hear from God through His Word and through others. No matter where you are in your faith journey, you are welcome to join us as you are every Sunday.

You can expect:

  • Authentic worship music so that we may praise Him together
  • Solid Biblical teaching that applies to your life
  • Real stories about what God is doing in people’s lives
  • Conversation and fellowship before and after each gathering

Our Sunday Services are at 10:30am on campus every week!

item.title: ESW Precious Plastics Project
item.description:
ESW Precious Plastics Project

Did you know that a lot of the cheap plastic bottles you recycle go to the landfill anyways? Our Precious Plastics project aims to mitigate harmful plastic waste by compacting those low-quality plastics into energy-efficient building materials (eco-bricks)!

Join us in using engineering and material concepts to construct our very own plastic eco-bricks.

No prior knowledge is needed, this project is open to students of every discipline!

For more information and updates check out our socials

Instagram: https://www.instagram.com/esw_ub/

Discord: https://discord.gg/w2BN2Ju3

From Monday, November 24, 2025 6:00 PM to 7:00 PM EST at Clemens 06.

item.title: IEEE GBM & Game Night
item.description:
IEEE GBM & Game Night

Learn what IEEE has to offer this year at our second General Body Meeting and Game Night!

During the first hour of this event, we will be going over what IEEE will be doing this year including:

- Arcade Machine: A fun and casual project building a custom arcade machine to play classic arcade games as well as classic console games. This project is great for people interested in video games, emulation, embedded systems, linux, woodworking, and painting! Of course, it is also a great way to just hang out and have fun playing video games!

- Automated Greenhouse: This project aims to create an autonomous greenhouse that can be used to grow and monitor plants with minimal human intervention. The goal is to keep plants alive and healthy by itself over long periods of time (such as over a winter or summer break). The goal for this year is to create a basic structure that can grow foods such as grape tomatoes and basil. This project is looking for people interested in web development, embedded systems, Internet of Things (IoT), gardening, sustainability, and building!

- Battlebots: Help build a Battlebot to compete in UB's annual botwars competition during engineering week! This is a great project for those interested in engineering design, mechanics, electronics, and power systems!

- Micromouse: Build an autonomous maze solving robot and compete against others! UB IEEE targets the annual Region 1 and 2 Micromouse Student Competition and annual Applied Power and Electronics (APEC) Micromouse Competition. This is a great opportunity for those who love embedded systems, software-hardware integration, competition, and working with a team!

- Workshops: IEEE hosts a series of workshops over the year covering topics including programming, embedded systems, Arduino, git && GitHub, 3D CAD modeling, and more. These are great avenues for inexperienced people to gain some skills to start working on IEEE's other projects, build a resume, or just learn something new.

 

This will be followed a short question and answer period with all of IEEE's officers and project leads.

Afterwards, join us for Game Night where we will have fun with board games, video games, and our own custom Arcade Machine! Pizza, snacks, and drinks will be served.

From Monday, November 24, 2025 5:30 PM to 8:45 PM EST at Nsc 228.

item.title: SASE General Body Meeting
item.description:
SASE General Body Meeting

Curious about what SASE is all about? Come learn more about the Society of Asian Scientists and Engineers (SASE) and the wide variety types of events we host throughout the year!

At SASE, we bring together students from all backgrounds to explore interests in science, engineering, and Asian culture. Our events include:

Engineering and Technical Activities: Battle Bots, egg drop and bridge competitions, resume workshops, professional headshots, and LinkedIn profile-building sessions, etc.

Cultural Events: Educational programs highlighting different Asian cultures, We teach and preform traditional dances with our performances, and large-scale celebrations like our hit Lunar New Year Festival from last year.

Social, Mentorship, and Bonding Events: Fun mixers, icebreakers, and opportunities to connect with peers and mentors, like our hit Squid games halloween event from last year, and our hit water festival event, etc.

Community Service: Activities focused on giving back and raising awareness about important issues within our community, like our preparations for the Buffalo science museum showcase, light the night, etc.

Whether you’re looking to grow professionally, learn about Asian cultures, meet new friends, or get involved on campus, learn about opportunities in the STEM field for Asians, SASE has something for you. Join us and be part of our vibrant community!

From Monday, November 24, 2025 7:00 PM to 9:00 PM EST at Nsc 218.

item.title: BASIC Weekly Meeting
item.description:
BASIC Weekly Meeting

Every Monday night our club meet for our weekly meetings. At these meetings, we start at 8:00 pm with worship songs followed by prayer and announcements. Each week we have a different speaker come and give a message relevant to the theme of the semester. They are introduced after announcements to give there 15–30-minute message. After the message men and women break up into small groups to further discuss the message. These small groups are a time to discuss the message and how it is relevant in our lives. Then we close in prayer for any student needs or general issues going on and the night ends with everyone enjoying a time of fellowship and catching up with new and old friends. 

From Monday, November 24, 2025 8:00 PM to 9:30 PM EST at SU 145 A+F+B+E.

item.title: Graduate Christian Fellowship (Cancelled)
item.description:
Graduate Christian Fellowship

The Graduate Christian Fellowship (GCF) at UB is a welcoming community of graduate students, professional students, and post-docs who are curious about Jesus and what his life, death, and resurrection mean for our work and for the world.

 

This semester, we are reading the book of Colossians, a letter that invites us to see all of life (our studies, our relationships, our work, and our world) through the lens of Christ. Written to a young community learning to follow Jesus in a complex cultural moment, Colossians speaks with surprising clarity to our own questions of identity, purpose, and hope.

From Tuesday, November 25, 2025 7:00 PM to 8:30 PM EST at Online.

item.title: Geography Graduate Students Writing Group
item.description:
Geography Graduate Students Writing Group

The graduate students' writing workshop is a place for graduate students in the Geography department to write together. This workshop lasts for two hours every week, where students have a focused time to write academic materials, like drafts of research papers, research proposals, dissertations, course assignments, or any other writing. Besides writing, you can also do other research work, like reading papers and analyzing data. This workshop has two main goals: (1) improve the productivity of students, and (2) to learn about the research work of peers. It is hybrid, so you can join in person or remotely. 

 

All attendees must review the GSA Safety Acknowledgement – Participation Disclaimer – Graduate Student Association before attending. 

From Wednesday, November 26, 2025 10:00 AM to 12:00 PM EST at Graduate Lounge, 401 Wilkeson Quad.

item.title: H2O Sunday Service
item.description:
H2O Sunday Service
 

The purpose of our Sunday Service is to gather together to worship God as a family. We believe that it is not just a meeting, but an opportunity to hear from God through His Word and through others. No matter where you are in your faith journey, you are welcome to join us as you are every Sunday.

You can expect:

  • Authentic worship music so that we may praise Him together
  • Solid Biblical teaching that applies to your life
  • Real stories about what God is doing in people’s lives
  • Conversation and fellowship before and after each gathering

Our Sunday Services are at 10:30am on campus every week! 

From Sunday, November 30, 2025 10:30 AM to 11:45 AM EST at SU 330 Pride & Tradition Assembly Hall.

item.title: ESW Precious Plastics Project
item.description:
ESW Precious Plastics Project

Did you know that a lot of the cheap plastic bottles you recycle go to the landfill anyways? Our Precious Plastics project aims to mitigate harmful plastic waste by compacting those low-quality plastics into energy-efficient building materials (eco-bricks)!

Join us in using engineering and material concepts to construct our very own plastic eco-bricks.

No prior knowledge is needed, this project is open to students of every discipline!

For more information and updates check out our socials

Instagram: https://www.instagram.com/esw_ub/

Discord: https://discord.gg/w2BN2Ju3

From Monday, December 1, 2025 6:00 PM to 7:00 PM EST at Clemens 06.

item.description:
Community Assistant Information Session
Come to an Information Session to learn more about the Community Assistant (CA) position for the 2026–2027 academic year at the University at Buffalo! This session will cover everything you need to know about the role, including responsibilities, renumeration, and how to apply. Being a CA is a great opportunity to build leadership skills, connect with the campus community, and make a positive impact in UB’s residence halls and apartments. Whether you're seriously considering applying or just want to explore your options, this session is a great place to start!
 
The Community Assistant (CA) is previously known as Resident Assistant (RA) and Academic Assistant (AA).

From Monday, December 1, 2025 6:00 PM to 7:00 PM EST at Online.

item.title: IAM3D Project Meeting
item.description:
IAM3D Project Meeting

MONDAYS AND FRIDAYS, 5pm @ Jarvis 305

Welcome to IAM3D! Come learn about CAD, 3D Printing, Electronics, Robotics and 3D Design as we work on our FPV Payload Mars Rover! We will be competing in the Innovative Additive Manufacturing 3D design competition (IAM3D) in April.

Our task is to design and build a first person view mars rover that can pick up different objects and drop them in a bucket, and the challenge is to 3D print as many parts as possible. Join our discord for more info and updates, hope to see you there! ASME discord (Meetings will be in Jarvis 305)

From Monday, December 1, 2025 5:00 PM to 7:45 PM EST at Jarvis 305.

item.title: BASIC Weekly Meeting
item.description:
BASIC Weekly Meeting

Every Monday night our club meet for our weekly meetings. At these meetings, we start at 8:00 pm with worship songs followed by prayer and announcements. Each week we have a different speaker come and give a message relevant to the theme of the semester. They are introduced after announcements to give there 15–30-minute message. After the message men and women break up into small groups to further discuss the message. These small groups are a time to discuss the message and how it is relevant in our lives. Then we close in prayer for any student needs or general issues going on and the night ends with everyone enjoying a time of fellowship and catching up with new and old friends. 

From Monday, December 1, 2025 8:00 PM to 9:30 PM EST at SU 145 A+F+B+E.

item.title: Feeling Your Yoga: Tuesdays with Cory
item.description:
Feeling Your Yoga: Tuesdays with Cory
This in-person yoga class consists of yoga postures/movements, meditation, and breath awareness to maintain balance and overall wellness through the challenges of the semester. It is not a fitness class, yet you may choose to test your limits. This class has extended relaxation time at the end. No experience is necessary. All levels are welcome, and all body types and sizes are honored. Dress comfortably. Please bring a towel/yoga mat and a water bottle. If you attend two classes, you can get a free yoga mat! Come every week or drop in when you can. Classes are first come, first serve. Arrive early to get a space in the class. Classes do fill up and may be closed upon arrival.

From Tuesday, December 2, 2025 6:15 PM to 7:15 PM EST at 11 Talbert Hall.

Life Groups are an essential weekly rhythm for H2O as they provide opportunity to know others and be known. item.title: Graduate Christian Fellowship (Cancelled)
item.description:
Graduate Christian Fellowship

The Graduate Christian Fellowship (GCF) at UB is a welcoming community of graduate students, professional students, and post-docs who are curious about Jesus and what his life, death, and resurrection mean for our work and for the world.

 

This semester, we are reading the book of Colossians, a letter that invites us to see all of life (our studies, our relationships, our work, and our world) through the lens of Christ. Written to a young community learning to follow Jesus in a complex cultural moment, Colossians speaks with surprising clarity to our own questions of identity, purpose, and hope.

From Tuesday, December 2, 2025 7:00 PM to 8:30 PM EST at Online.
item.author: chris.sullivan@intervarsity.org (Intervarsity Christian Fellowship)

item.title: Geography Graduate Students Writing Group
item.description:
Geography Graduate Students Writing Group

The graduate students' writing workshop is a place for graduate students in the Geography department to write together. This workshop lasts for two hours every week, where students have a focused time to write academic materials, like drafts of research papers, research proposals, dissertations, course assignments, or any other writing. Besides writing, you can also do other research work, like reading papers and analyzing data. This workshop has two main goals: (1) improve the productivity of students, and (2) to learn about the research work of peers. It is hybrid, so you can join in person or remotely. 

 

All attendees must review the GSA Safety Acknowledgement – Participation Disclaimer – Graduate Student Association before attending. 

From Wednesday, December 3, 2025 10:00 AM to 12:00 PM EST at Graduate Lounge, 401 Wilkeson Quad.

item.title: IEEE Micromouse and Automated Greenhouse Project Meeting
item.description:
IEEE Micromouse and Automated Greenhouse Project Meeting

IEEE will be hosting the weekly meeting for Micromouse and Automated Greenhouse during this meeting time. 

Micromouse: Build an autonomous maze solving robot and compete against others! UB IEEE targets the annual Region 1 and 2 Micromouse Student Competition and annual Applied Power and Electronics (APEC) Micromouse Competition. This is a great opportunity for those who love embedded systems, software-hardware integration, competition, and working with a team! Our individual small micromouse teams will continue to work on their own maze-solving robots. 

Automated Greenhouse: This project aims to create an autonomous greenhouse that can be used to grow and monitor plants with minimal human intervention. The goal is to keep plants alive and healthy by itself over long periods of time (such as over a winter or summer break). The goal for this year is to create a basic structure that can grow foods such as grape tomatoes and basil. This project is looking for people interested in web development, embedded systems, Internet of Things (IoT), gardening, sustainability, and building! 

 

From Wednesday, December 3, 2025 4:30 PM to 7:30 PM EST at Bonner 416.

item.title: Philosophy, Politics, and Economics Club Weekly Meeting
item.description:
Philosophy, Politics, and Economics Club Weekly Meeting

The purpose of the Philosophy, Politics, and Economics (PPE) Club is to provide a space for the open discussion of topics related to the intersection of philosophy, political science, and economics and foster an intellectual community based on mutual respect and curiosity. Join us each week for great conversations about unique topics, lots of fun, and a community like no other on campus (and also pizza).

PPE Club is open to people of all majors and disciplines. Regardless of your background, knowledge of the topics, or future aspirations, PPE Club has something for everyone! PPE Club also serves to connect students with the academic and professional opportunities that are available for those passionate about the humanities and social sciences. Students have made connections through PPE Club that led them to research opportunities, internships, and more. We hope to see you there!

From Thursday, December 4, 2025 5:00 PM to 6:00 PM EST at SU 210 Landmark Room.

item.title: Pure Monotheism: Understanding Tawheed
item.description:
Pure Monotheism: Understanding Tawheed

“Pure Monotheism: Understanding Tawheed” is an in-depth look at the Islamic belief in the oneness of Allah, known as tawheed. It covers how the early generations of Muslims (the Salaf) understood and explained this core aspect of faith, including its categories, meanings, and relevance to a Muslim’s worship and daily life.

From Thursday, December 4, 2025 5:00 PM to 8:30 PM EST at O'Brian 112.

item.title: SASE General Body Meeting
item.description:
SASE General Body Meeting

Curious about what SASE is all about? Come learn more about the Society of Asian Scientists and Engineers (SASE) and the wide variety types of events we host throughout the year!

At SASE, we bring together students from all backgrounds to explore interests in science, engineering, and Asian culture. Our events include:

Engineering and Technical Activities: Battle Bots, egg drop and bridge competitions, resume workshops, professional headshots, and LinkedIn profile-building sessions, etc.

Cultural Events: Educational programs highlighting different Asian cultures, We teach and preform traditional dances with our performances, and large-scale celebrations like our hit Lunar New Year Festival from last year.

Social, Mentorship, and Bonding Events: Fun mixers, icebreakers, and opportunities to connect with peers and mentors, like our hit Squid games halloween event from last year, and our hit water festival event, etc.

Community Service: Activities focused on giving back and raising awareness about important issues within our community, like our preparations for the Buffalo science museum showcase, light the night, etc.

Whether you’re looking to grow professionally, learn about Asian cultures, meet new friends, or get involved on campus, learn about opportunities in the STEM field for Asians, SASE has something for you. Join us and be part of our vibrant community!

From Thursday, December 4, 2025 7:00 PM to 9:00 PM EST at Knox 04.
item.author: ubsase@gmail.com (Society of Asian Scientists & Engineers)

item.title: E-Board Meetings

item.description:
Weekly UB FAN Fridays (GBM via Zoom)

Join us for a weekly virtual open space where UB FAN Leaders and Alumni Mentors come together to connect, share, and support one another. These informal sessions blend office hours, alumni highlights, and community-building topics to foster meaningful engagement between students and alumni. Whether you have questions, want to hear inspiring stories, or just want to pop in and say hi — all are welcome! Sessions will be led by Laura Masse (Assistant Director of Early Engagement) and FAN Managers, Emaan Sohail and Dessi Furber. Questions or want to formally join UB FAN? Email us as UBFutureAlumni@buffalo.edu.

item.title: CSTEP Research Luncheon B
item.description:
CSTEP Research Luncheon B

You're invited to our CSTEP Research Luncheon B on Friday, December 5, 2025 at Noon in 107 Capen (Honors. Lunch will be provided. You must RSVP via the link below. This is a great time to ask questions about their faculty-mentored research experience and our Summer Research Program and to hear about what CSTEP has to offer. Please note this event is for Undergraduates only as CSTEP is a program for Undergraduate students. This event is for CSTEP students and those who are interested in applying to CSTEP. 

Get a first-hand look at the amazing work our research interns who are talented underrepresented students in STEM in and the licensed professions. This is a great time to ask questions about their faculty-mentored research experience and our Summer Research Program and to hear about what CSTEP has to offer.

RSVP by Wednesday, December 3, at https://www.tinyurl.com/CSTEPResearchLunchB

From Friday, December 5, 2025 12:00 PM to 1:30 PM EST at 107 Capen Hall (Honors).

item.title: Cause Connection
item.description:
Cause Connection

Cause Connection events are on-campus, micro-volunteering opportunities that are designed to allow students to give back to their community. Students can come to these events to make connections with their peers over shared passions for social justice issues- topics change each month! In the past, students have assembled hygiene kits for Dignity Grows, prepared seeds for Grassroots Garden events, written letters of appreciation and encouragement for Compass House. 

From Friday, December 5, 2025 12:00 PM to 2:00 PM EST at SU 145.

item.title: Gingerbread House Decorating
item.description:
Gingerbread House Decorating

Take a study break and celebrate the season with The Women’s Network at our Gingerbread House Decorating Event! We’ll provide everything you need — pre-built houses, colorful candies, mountains of frosting, and plenty of inspiration. Whether you’re a meticulous architect or a freestyle decorator, this is your chance to get creative and let your holiday spirit shine.

Spend the afternoon laughing with friends, meeting new people, and showing off your best winter wonderland design. You can go classic and cozy, build a candy-covered palace, or even turn your house into a quirky masterpiece — there’s no wrong way to decorate!

This is a relaxed, come-as-you-are event — perfect for taking a breather before finals and wrapping up the semester on a sweet note.

Date & Time: 4:00pm- 5:00pm
Location: Obrian 212

Bring your creativity, your appetite, and your holiday cheer — we can’t wait to see the incredible houses you come up with!

From Friday, December 5, 2025 4:00 PM to 5:00 PM EST at Obrian 212.
item.author: thewomensnetwork.buffalo@gmail.com (The Women's Network: Buffalo)

item.title: AIAA DBF (Design Build Fly) Build Meeting
item.description:
AIAA DBF (Design Build Fly) Build Meeting

UB AIAA is an engineering club that offers students hands-on experience with real-world aerospace challenges. The main project is Design/Build/Fly (DBF), an international competition hosted by AIAA, Textron Aviation, and Raytheon. DBF challenges teams to design, build, and fly a custom radio-controlled aircraft that meets a unique set of mission requirements. The club holds several meetings throughout the academic year to design and manufacture their RC aircraft. These meetings can range from CADing molds and parts of the plane, running tests to choose the airfoil shape, and hands-on meetings where members can work with carbon fiber or other materials to build the plane.

From Friday, December 5, 2025 6:00 PM to 7:00 PM EST at Furnas Hall, Lab 1025.
item.author: buffaloaiaa@gmail.com (UB Chapter American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics)
item.host: UB Chapter American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics

item.title: IAM3D Project Meeting
item.description:
IAM3D Project Meeting

MONDAYS AND FRIDAYS, 5pm @ Jarvis 305

Welcome to IAM3D! Come learn about CAD, 3D Printing, Electronics, Robotics and 3D Design as we work on our FPV Payload Mars Rover! We will be competing in the Innovative Additive Manufacturing 3D design competition (IAM3D) in April.

Our task is to design and build a first person view mars rover that can pick up different objects and drop them in a bucket, and the challenge is to 3D print as many parts as possible. Join our discord for more info and updates, hope to see you there! ASME discord (Meetings will be in Jarvis 305)

From Friday, December 5, 2025 5:00 PM to 7:45 PM EST at Jarvis 305.

item.title: 3rd Annual LV Shakespeare Showcase
item.description:
3rd Annual LV Shakespeare Showcase

3rd Annual LV Shakespeare Showcase

Directed by Andre White as part of our Student Directed Series

Dec. 6, 2025 at 7:30 p.m.

UB Katharine Cornell Theatre

Tickets: https://www.ticketmaster.com/event/000062E7B7F36DC9

 

$25 Adults | $20 Seniors/Veterans/UB Employees

$15 Students/Children | $10 UB Students

(Ticketmaster fees apply when purchasing online.)

 

Theatre student Andre White will host the 3rd Annual Shakespeare Showcase, featuring undergraduate student performers. The informal, fifty-five minute long program includes a compilation of monologues, sonnets, and scenes from across Shakespeare's works.

 

The UB Theatre and Dance 2025-2026 season is sponsored in part by Fox Run at Orchard Park, celebrating its seventh year in support of the department.

From Saturday, December 6, 2025 7:30 PM to 9:30 PM EST at Katharine Cornell Theatre.

item.title: H2O Sunday Service
item.description:
H2O Sunday Service
 

The purpose of our Sunday Service is to gather together to worship God as a family. We believe that it is not just a meeting, but an opportunity to hear from God through His Word and through others. No matter where you are in your faith journey, you are welcome to join us as you are every Sunday.

You can expect:

  • Authentic worship music so that we may praise Him together
  • Solid Biblical teaching that applies to your life
  • Real stories about what God is doing in people’s lives
  • Conversation and fellowship before and after each gathering

Our Sunday Services are at 10:30am on campus every week! 

From Sunday, December 7, 2025 10:30 AM to 11:45 AM EST at SU 330 Pride & Tradition Assembly Hall.
item.author: h2ochurchbuffalo@gmail.com (H2O Church)

item.title: UB Badminton Open Play
item.description:
UB Badminton Open Play

UB Badminton hosts a weekly open play session every Sunday from 11 AM to 2 PM at the Triple Gym Alumni Arena. Players of all skill levels are welcome to join. We have 8 courts available, and we provide rackets and used birdies. The back 4 courts have a 20-minute rotation, while the front 4 courts operate on a waitlist system, allowing players up to 2 sets of games.

Please remember to bring your UBLINKED event pass for check-in. If you need to borrow a racket, be sure to bring your ID for rental. We look forward to seeing you on Sundays and hope you have a fantastic time at our open play session!

From Sunday, December 7, 2025 11:00 AM to 2:00 PM EST at Triple Gym, Alumni Arena.

item.title: ESW Precious Plastics Project
item.description:
ESW Precious Plastics Project

Did you know that a lot of the cheap plastic bottles you recycle go to the landfill anyways? Our Precious Plastics project aims to mitigate harmful plastic waste by compacting those low-quality plastics into energy-efficient building materials (eco-bricks)!

Join us in using engineering and material concepts to construct our very own plastic eco-bricks.

No prior knowledge is needed, this project is open to students of every discipline!

For more information and updates check out our socials

Instagram: https://www.instagram.com/esw_ub/

Discord: https://discord.gg/w2BN2Ju3

From Monday, December 8, 2025 6:00 PM to 7:00 PM EST at Clemens 06.

item.description:
IAM3D Project Meeting

MONDAYS AND FRIDAYS, 5pm @ Jarvis 305

Welcome to IAM3D! Come learn about CAD, 3D Printing, Electronics, Robotics and 3D Design as we work on our FPV Payload Mars Rover! We will be competing in the Innovative Additive Manufacturing 3D design competition (IAM3D) in April.

Our task is to design and build a first person view mars rover that can pick up different objects and drop them in a bucket, and the challenge is to 3D print as many parts as possible. Join our discord for more info and updates, hope to see you there! ASME discord (Meetings will be in Jarvis 305)

item.title: WHWA GBM Fall Semester
item.description:
WHWA GBM Fall Semester

The WHWA is an on-campus organization dedicated to promoting and advocating for the equitable healthcare and overall wellness of all women. This includes educating our community about various topics that we discuss at our general body meetings such as sexual wellness, domestic violence awareness, types of contraception methods, mental health resources, diseases & disorders that disproportionately impact women, etc. We are committed to empowering women from all backgrounds, cultures, and gender identities with holistic health information. We encourage everyone to join us to learn about and discuss various topics surrounding women's health. 

From Monday, December 8, 2025 7:00 PM to 8:00 PM EST at Clemens 120.

item.description:
Community Assistant Information Session
Come to an Information Session to learn more about the Community Assistant (CA) position for the 2026–2027 academic year at the University at Buffalo! This session will cover everything you need to know about the role, including responsibilities, renumeration, and how to apply. Being a CA is a great opportunity to build leadership skills, connect with the campus community, and make a positive impact in UB’s residence halls and apartments. Whether you're seriously considering applying or just want to explore your options, this session is a great place to start!
 
The Community Assistant (CA) is previously known as Resident Assistant (RA) and Academic Assistant (AA).

From Monday, December 8, 2025 8:00 PM to 9:00 PM EST at 330 Student Union.

item.title: BASIC Weekly Meeting
item.description:
BASIC Weekly Meeting

Every Monday night our club meet for our weekly meetings. At these meetings, we start at 8:00 pm with worship songs followed by prayer and announcements. Each week we have a different speaker come and give a message relevant to the theme of the semester. They are introduced after announcements to give there 15–30-minute message. After the message men and women break up into small groups to further discuss the message. These small groups are a time to discuss the message and how it is relevant in our lives. Then we close in prayer for any student needs or general issues going on and the night ends with everyone enjoying a time of fellowship and catching up with new and old friends. 

From Monday, December 8, 2025 8:00 PM to 9:30 PM EST at SU 145 A+F+B+E.

item.title: Graduate Christian Fellowship (Cancelled)
item.description:
Graduate Christian Fellowship

The Graduate Christian Fellowship (GCF) at UB is a welcoming community of graduate students, professional students, and post-docs who are curious about Jesus and what his life, death, and resurrection mean for our work and for the world.

 

This semester, we are reading the book of Colossians, a letter that invites us to see all of life (our studies, our relationships, our work, and our world) through the lens of Christ. Written to a young community learning to follow Jesus in a complex cultural moment, Colossians speaks with surprising clarity to our own questions of identity, purpose, and hope.

From Tuesday, December 9, 2025 7:00 PM to 8:30 PM EST at Online.

item.description:

The intended audience for this class is international students, visiting scholars, or their spouses.
